div.p: The following Help Topics are available:

This grammar file is intended as an outline account of the most important and central grammatical constructions in Russian. It is designed to enable you to master the fundamental structure of Russian as quickly as possible. Stress is shown for all forms. Vocabulary has been kept to a minimum, because its mastery is an ongoing process even for native speakers.
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Russian belongs to the Slavic branch of the Indo-European family of languages. Its roots are in Common or Proto-Slavic, which began to develop near the end of the third millennium BC, when Indo-European settlers scattered across Eastern Europe. Extensive migrations in the 5th and 6th centuries AD gradually led to the current division of Slavic languages into West, South, and East branches. The West Slavic languages now include Polish, Czech, and Slovak; the major South Slavic languages are Serbian, Croatian, Slovenian, Macedonian, and Bulgarian; and Russian, Ukrainian, and Byelorussian are East Slavic tongues.

There is no conclusive evidence of a written Slavic language until the 9th century AD, when Prince Rostislav of Moravia (now the Czech Republic) asked Byzantine Emperor Michael III to supply Slavic-speaking teachers. In AD 863 two brothers, Cyril (827-869) and Methodius (826-885) led the mission to Christianize the Slavic tribes. They were apparently from the city of Thessalonika, the heart of a Slavic-speaking region of Greece. Their native tongue is now known as Old Church Slavic; at the time this South Slavic language displayed only minor dialectical differences from the West Slavic language of the Moravians, so mutual understanding would not have posed great difficulties.

Cyril and Methodius created an alphabet to suit the existing oral language and used it to translate parts of the Gospels and the Orthodox liturgy. By the time of Methodius' death in 885, many works had been translated from the Greek, and original works, including poetry, were beginning to appear. There is some scholarly disagreement on the subject, but the alphabet Cyril and Methodius created was probably what is known as the Glagolitic alphabet. Near the end of the 9th century it was replaced by Cyrillic, which was named after Cyril but probably was a later invention by one of his disciples. Cyrillic is based mostly on the Greek uncial script, with a few new letters and a few borrowed from other languages, including Hebrew. In any case, the missionary effort and the alphabet gradually moved southeast. The conversion of Russia to Orthodoxy in AD 988 permanently established the written language in Russia, the cultural and political center of which was then Kiev (now in Ukraine).

A linguistic condition known as diglossia arose as two related but distinct languages began to coexist, each serving specific purposes within the culture -- Old Church Slavic (also called Old Church Slavonic and Old Bulgarian) for formal, official, and religious settings, and Old Russian for everyday use. Inevitably, the two languages influenced each other; modern Russian includes many remnants of Old Church Slavic. (Compare the similar influence of Latin on Italian.) The Russian Orthodox liturgy is still in a more modern Church Slavic. Between the late 13th and the 16th centuries Old Russian, the common East Slavic language, split into Russian, Ukrainian, and Byelorussian.

The Russian lexicon began with largely Slavic roots and extensive borrowing from Greek, largely via Old Church Slavic. Cultural and political changes over the centuries have contributed to extensive borrowing from Turkic languages, French, German, and English. Russian Emperor Peter the Great, who ruled Russia from 1682 to 1725, presided over dramatically increased Russian contact with Western Europe. French influence was especially strong; as late as the 19th century, members of the Russian nobility often spoke French more fluently than their native Russian. The strongest English and German influence came somewhat later, and since World War II Russian has shown a marked preference for adopting American English words (with British pronunciation), particularly slang and technological terms.

Like Latin and German, Russian is a case language, using inflected forms of nouns and adjectives (typically, different word endings) more than word order to indicate grammatical function. Word order in Russian is hardly free or random -- variations signal differences in emphasis, meaning, or viewpoint -- but it is far more flexible than in languages such as English and Bulgarian, which have mostly lost their case system. (Some suggestion of the lost case system in English is observed in variation between subject and object forms of pronouns: I/me, he/him, she/her, we/us, they/them.)

Russian and other Slavic languages have a grammatical category that other Indo-European languages do not: verb aspect. Verbs either belong to the perfective (marked) category, which typically emphasizes the beginning or completion of an action, or the action as a whole; or they belong to the imperfective (unmarked) category, which tends to emphasize the action itself. For the beginning student, this characteristic, combined with verb conjugation (such as exists in French, Spanish, and German, but is radically simplified in English), tends to obscure the fact that the Russian verb tense system has undergone dramatic simplification over the centuries and is now quite streamlined in comparison with that of other European languages, including English.

Russian has about 150 million speakers in Russia and other former Soviet republics. There are many dialects, but those of St. Petersburg and Moscow are considered standard. Grammar, spelling rules, the alphabet, and pronunciation have evolved considerably over the centuries; notably, the alphabet was "reformed" shortly after the October Revolution of 1917. Certain letters were eliminated, for example, and the hard sign at the end of many words was dropped. The pre-revolutionary alphabet can still be seen in pre-revolutionary publications, and also in some more recent materials published outside Russia.

There are thirty-three letters in the Russian alphabet, but up to fifty different and distinct sounds. The letters of the Russian alphabet are presented below with an approximation of the most common sounds associated with them. (Please note that these are truly approximations, since Russian articulation differs from English for almost all of these sounds.) For consonants, the chart includes voiced / unvoiced pronunciation. For vowels, it includes stressed (and first position for е, л, ю, я) / unstressed pronunciation.

td.p: a in ma / e in mess
b in boy / p in step
v in voice / f in clef
g in girl / k in pack
d in dog / t in plot
ye in yes / ea in ear
s in pleasure / sh in brush
z in zoo / s in loose
ee in bee / i in hit
e in egg / e in debate
o in more / a in ma

The 33 letters of the Russian alphabet can produce over 50 distinct sounds. To understand the changes in pronunciation that letters undergo, it is necessary to understand the Russian sound system.
See Russian Sound System.
A table of the Russian alphabet with the most common sounds each letter represents is presented in Letters and Sounds.

There are 33 letters in the Russian alphabet, consisting of 21 consonants (included here is the letter й), 10 vowels, and two signs, the soft sign ь and the hard sign ъ. The Russian sound system includes both hard and soft consonants, and hard and "softening" vowels. Most letters can represent different sounds depending on various factors including:
- position in a stressed or unstressed syllable; and
- position next to another letter.

The sounds of any language are generally divided into two main groups - vowels and consonants. All vowels are produced with voice, that is, with vibration of the vocal cords. But with consonants, the outward flow of sound is interrupted or diverted by one of the articulators - the teeth, tongue, lips, or palate.
In Russian, there are five vowel pairs of corresponding hard and "softening" vowels:

It is important to note that the "softening" vowels are called so because they soften or palatalize the pronunciation of the preceding consonant. The vowel sound itself does not change. For information on how the pronunciation of a preceding consonant is affected, see Hard and Soft Consonants.

Many English vowels are pronounced as diphthongs, which means that one vowel actually incorporates two vowel sounds. When you pronounce the word 'I,' there are actually two vowel sounds produced: 'ah - ee.' In Russian, vowels do not become diphthongized. They produce just one distinct sound. There are two exceptions to this rule:

1. Й, the short ee (и краткое), combines with vowels to affect their pronunciation. This letter appears only after vowels (except for a few words of foreign origin where it appears first to represent the 'y' sound). It causes the same vowel sound as the 'y' in 'boy.' The й, short ee, is usually considered a consonant or semi-vowel.

2. When the letters е, л, ю, я are in the first position in a word, follow another vowel, or follow the soft or hard signs, ь, ъ, they are pronounced with the 'y' sound represented by й in Russian. This produces the diphthongs 'ye, yo, yu, ya.' When these letters appear after a consonant, they soften the pronunciation of the preceding consonant. Compare:

See Also:
Consonants
Hard and Soft Consonants

Letters and Sounds
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
When consonants are pronounced, the outward flow of air is interrupted or diverted by the teeth, tongue, lips, or palate. Consonants are classified according to the manner of articulation as follows:
Gutturals (or Velars) (produced with the back of the tongue and the velum, or soft palate): г, к, х
"Hushers" (producing a hushing sound): ж, ч, ш, щ
Dentals (produced with tongue against teeth): д, з, н, л, р, с, т, ц
Labio-dentals (produced with lower lip and upper teeth): ф, в
Labials (produced with upper and lower lips): б, м, п
Letters are further classified as voiced and voiceless.

See Also:
Hard and Soft Consonants
Devoicing of Final Consonants
Vowels and Diphthongs
Letters and Sounds
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Most Russian consonants can be pronounced hard or soft. The soft pronunciation of a consonant is caused by a following softening vowel or ь. The sound change of consonants caused by a following vowel or soft sign is called palatalization. A palatalized, or softened, consonant is pronounced with the tongue raised toward the roof of the mouth. Compare:
дядя - дом
The pronunciation of some consonants cannot be changed by a following vowel. The letters ж, ш, ц are always pronounced hard and the letters й, ч, щ are always pronounced soft.
See Spelling of Consonant/Vowel Combinations.

See Also:
Consonants
Devoicing of Final Consonants
Vowels and Diphthongs
Letters and Sounds
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Russian consonants can be described as voiced and voiceless. This distinction exists for English consonants as well. The difference is that some of the voiced consonants in Russian become voiceless when they appear in final position in a word. The voiced consonants л, м, н, р, й are never pronounced without voice.
The voiced consonants include: б, в, д, г, ж, з, л, м, н, р, й.
The voiceless consonants include: к, п, с, т, ф, х, ц, ч, ш, щ.

As their names indicate, the voiced consonants require voice to be produced and the voiceless consonants can be produced merely with the passage of air. Note that the voiced consonants cause a vibration of the vocal cords and the voiceless do not.

Parts of speech are the basic building blocks of any language grammar. They include nouns, verbs, adjectives, pronouns, adverbs, prepositions, conjunctions, articles, and interjections.

See Also:
History of the Russian Language
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

A noun is a word that names a person, place, thing, or idea. Every noun displays three characteristics that affect its ending: case, gender, and number. Case gives a noun its grammatical context in a sentence. The declension of a noun is the presentation of a noun with its six different case endings. Gender can be masculine, neuter, or feminine. The number of a noun is either singular or plural.

Another important concept to understand with regard to Russian nouns is animacy. A noun referring to an animate being is treated differently than one referring to an inanimate object. This distinction is observed only in the accusative case and is noted in all of the declension charts of Russian nouns.
Numerals affect the case of the noun they modify. For a description of the rules regarding numerals and case, see Numerals.
For examples of nouns forming phrases and clauses, see Noun Phrases and Noun Clauses.
To learn about noun prefixes, suffixes, and compound nouns, see Noun Formation.

See Also:
Noun-Adjective Agreement

A proper noun is the name of a particular person, place, or thing. It begins with a capital letter in writing. Compare the proper nouns with the common nouns:
Other proper nouns included names of organizations, companies etc.:
Микрософт (Microsoft)
Эпл Компьютер (Apple Computer)
газета Известия (the newspaper "The News")
Geographic locations such as countries, cities, rivers, streets etc.:
Голландия (Holland), Лондон (London)
Names of historic events and documents:
Великая Отечественная война (World War II)
декларация Независимости (the Declaration of Independence)
Names of holidays:
Первое мая (First of May)
Новый год (New Year)
An important difference between proper nouns in English and Russian is that, as a rule, only the first word in a proper noun phrase is capitalized in Russian. For example:
Война и мир (War and Peace)
Russian Names
Personal names in Russian include the first name имя, second (patronymic) отчество, and the last or surname, фамилия.
First names include:
Николай (Nicholas), Плтр (Peter), Иван (John)
Людмила (Ludmila), Мария (Maria), Надежда (Hope)
Note that there are many diminutive variations of first names. For example:
Иван (John) can also be called:
Ваня, Ванька, Ванюшка, Ванечка (Johnny)
Patronymics :
Иванович (son of John), Петрович (son of Peter),
Николаевна (daughter of Nicholas), Викторовна (daughter of Victor)
Last or surnames:
Плоткин (Plotkin (Carpenter)), Кузнецов (Kuznetsov (Smith))
Note that the days of the week and months are not capitalized in Russian:
воскресенье (Sunday)
апрель (April)

All nouns that are not proper nouns are called common. Nouns are subdivided into countable and noncount. Countable nouns can be singular and plural and can answer the question:
как много...?, сколько? (how much, how many?)
Сколько курсов ты берлшь в этом семестре?
(How many courses are you taking this semester?)
Collective Nouns
Collective nouns describe groups of people, animals, or objects which constitute a single unit :
аудитория (audience), стадо (herd), класс (class), толпа (crowd), оркестр (orchestra), команда (team)
Some collective nouns are countable (can be singular and plural):
Все соседние семьи собрались для обсуждения.
(All the families in the neighborhood got together for the discussion.)
Вся семья была взволнована новостью.
(The whole family was excited by the news.)

Вся семья (the whole family) in the second example means 'all of the members of the family' and is a singular collective noun. In Russian the collective noun which functions as a subject of the sentence requires a verb in the singular:
Жюри решило подчиниться закону.
(The jury decided to comply with the law.)
Жюри (jury) is singular. It is a neuter indeclinable noun of foreign origin.
Abstract Nouns
Abstract nouns are words for concepts and ideas:
человечество (humanity), доброта (kindness), красота (beauty), ненависть (hatred), рост (growth)

The distinction between animate and inanimate nouns appeared in Russian only in the 16th to 17th centuries. In the beginning, it included only masculine nouns denoting persons and professions. Only gradually did it embrace all other nouns. Now, Russian classifies all nouns as animate or inanimate.

The masculine singular accusative of animate nouns is the same as the masculine singular genitive. To distinguish between the subject and direct object (nominative and accusative respectively), the masculine accusative singular of animate nouns has the same form as the genitive and different from the nominative masculine singular.
Мальчик любит отца (The boy loves (his) father)
and
Отец любит мальчика. (The father loves the boy.)
The accusative masculine singular forms мальчика, отца are different from the nominative masculine singular forms, мальчик, отец.
The masculine singular accusative of inanimate nouns is the same as the masculine singular nominative.
Отец любит дом. (The father loves the house)

The accusative singular form for an inanimate masculine noun, дом, is the same as the nominative singular, дом. Logically, the subject and object of this sentence could not be confused, as is the case with most inanimate objects in sentences.
The plural accusative of all animate nouns is the same as plural genitive.
Девочки любят бабушек. (The girls love (their) grandmothers.)
and
Бабушки любят девочек. (The grandmothers love the girls.)
The accusative plural forms бабушек, девочек are different from nominative plural forms девочки, бабушки.
The plural accusative of all inanimate nouns is the same as plural nominative.
Мальчики любят игры. (The boys love games.)
The accusative plural form for the inanimate noun игры is the same as the nominative plural игры.

Some nouns are usually used only in the singular. These include collective nouns, such as крыжовник, 'gooseberries', and nouns that refer to qualities or feelings, грусть, 'sadness.'
These can include whole groups of similar items (they are also called mass nouns):
оборудование (equipment), еда (food), почта (mail)
Fluids:
вода (water), кофе (coffee), чай (tea), молоко (milk), масло (oil), кровь (blood), бензин (gasoline)
Solids:
ллд (ice), мясо (meat), золото (gold), хлопок (cotton),
дерево (wood)
Gases:
воздух (air), кислород (oxygen), пар (steam)
Particles:
рис (rice), кукуруза (corn), пыль (dust), мука (flour), сахар (sugar)
Abstract nouns:
уверенность (confidence), образование (education), удовольствие (pleasure), здоровье (health), помощь (help), честность (honesty)
Sports, games, and activities:
бейсбол (baseball), футбол (soccer), покер (poker)
Nature:
природа (nature), роса (dew), темнота (darkness), свет (light), тепло (heat)
Noncount nouns can occasionally be plural. In the plural, they express large quantities, long duration, or repetition:
южные ветры (southern winds)
осенние дожди (fall rains)
территориальные воды (territorial waters)
вечные снега (eternal snows)
They can also denote a whole class consisting of different items:
итальянские вина (Italian wines)
французские сыры (French cheeses)

Some nouns can only be plural, and denote inseparable things, or those that come in pairs, for example:
очки (glasses), штаны / брюки (pants), санки (sled), коньки (ice skates)
Mass nouns:
сливки (cream), слюни (saliva), сласти (sweets)
Nouns denoting time duration and events:
сутки (24 hours), каникулы (vacation), сумерки (twilight), похороны (burial),
именины (saint's day; birthday celebration), крестины (baptism)
For nouns having only a singular form, see Noncount Nouns.

In Russian, all nouns have a grammatical gender: feminine, masculine, or neuter.
Masculine and neuter nouns belong to the first declension pattern. Feminine nouns are either second or third declension. See Declension of Nouns.

Personal pronouns can be used to replace nouns of all three genders. See
Personal Pronouns.

Masculine nouns end in consonants, -й or -ь:
кот (cat), дом (house), чай (tea),
день (day), театр (theater)
Nouns ending in -ь can be either feminine or masculine. A few rules may be helpful in determining the gender of these nouns.
1. Nouns ending in -ь that refer to men are masculine:
царь (tsar)
2. All names of the months are masculine:
январь (January)
февраль (February)
июль (July)
3. Nouns denoting professions are usually masculine. However, even though there is a feminine form for these professional titles, the masculine form can be used to refer to both sexes.
писатель (writer)
учитель (teacher)
водитель (driver)
Some masculine nouns have feminine endings -а and -я in the nominative case and are declined as feminine nouns:
дядя, (uncle), папа (dad), старшина (leader), мужчина (man), юноша (youth)
Some proper names and masculine diminutives also have feminine endings in -а and -я in the nominative case and are declined as feminine nouns:
дядюшка (uncle), папочка (daddy), дедушка (grandpa), сынишка (sonny), Никита (Nikita), Ваня (diminutive of Иван, John), Толя (diminutive of Анатолий, Anatole), etc.
Note that even though such nouns decline as feminine nouns, any adjectives that modify them will be masculine.
Some nouns can apply to both male and female persons. They decline as feminine nouns according to their nominative endings -а and -я:
калека (cripple), заика (stutterer), пьяница (drunkard), сирота (orphan), невежа (ignoramus), неряха (slob), убийца (murderer), умница (smart person)
Some nouns with diminutive and augmentative suffixes ending in -о and -е
are masculine:
домишко (small house from дом house), городишко (small town, from город town), домище (big house, from дом house)

Feminine nouns end in -а and -я or -ь:
мама (mother), книга (book), вода (water),
песня (song), мышь (mouse), весть (news)
Some abstract nouns are feminine:
красота (beauty), высота (height), грубость (rudeness),
тонкость (thinness), тишина (silence)
Nouns ending in -жь, -знь, -мь, пь, -фь, -чь, -шь, -щь are feminine:
ночь (night), вещь (thing), тишь (silence)

Neuter nouns end in -о and -е or -л:
окно (window), письмо (letter), море (sea),
ружьл (gun), знание (knowledge)
Some abstract nouns are neuter:
знание (knowledge), условие (condition), страдание (suffering)
Ten nouns ending with -мя are neuter:
имя (name), время (time), бремя (burden), племя (tribe), знамя (banner), семя (seed), пламя (flame), вымя (udder), темя (top of the head), стремя (stirrup)
They constitute a special group of nouns that insert -ен in their declension.
Inanimate nouns borrowed from foreign languages are usually neuter.
Some of these coincidentally end in -о and -е:
пальто (overcoat), кино (movies), метро (subway), кафе (cafe), радио (radio)
Other borrowed inanimate nouns do not.
такси (taxi), интервью (interview), ревю (review)
Both of these sets of borrowed nouns require adjectives and other affected words to show the neuter endings even though these words do not decline themselves:
Note that animate nouns of the same type are masculine:
маэстро (maestro), атташе (attache)

or substantivized adjectives, are used as nouns, yet declined like adjectives. This occurs when an adjective acquires the meaning of a noun phrase. For example, гостиная комната (living room) is usually referred to simply as гостиная.
Он вошлл в гостиную.
(He entered the living room.)
Adjectival nouns always reflect the gender of the omitted noun. Some of them are used today only as nouns, while most retain their ability to act as adjectives. For example:
согласный (consonant) and гласный (vowel) refer to the masculine noun звук, 'sound'.
насекомое (insect) and животное (animal) refer to the neuter noun существо, 'being'.
настоящее (the present) and будущее (the future) refer to the neuter noun время, 'time'.

Nouns decline according to one of three declension patterns. Most masculine and neuter nouns belong to the first declension. Most feminine nouns ending with -а, -я belong to the second declension. Feminine nouns ending with a soft sign belong to the third declension.
Masculine First Declension Nouns:
кот (cat), учитель (teacher, masc.), дождь (rain), герой (hero)
Neuter First Declension Nouns:
дело (affair, matter), солнце (sun), знание (knowledge), ружьл (rifle)
Feminine Second Declension Nouns:
мама (mother), земля (land), учительница (teacher, fem.)
Note: There are several masculine nouns belonging to this declension pattern, including:
дядя (uncle), юноша (youth)
Feminine Third Declension Nouns:
мышь (mouse), кровать (bed)

Declension patterns are distinguished from one another by the endings of the genitive singular. For the first declension, this is -а or -я; for the second declension, this is -ы or -и; for the third declension, this is -и.

There are also some neuter nouns which do not follow any of these patterns, specifically the ten words ending in - мя: имя (name), время (time), бремя (burden), племя (tribe), знамя (banner), семя (seed), пламя (flame), вымя (udder), темя (top of the head), and стремя (stirrup). Most words that end in -мя use the first declension endings for the Nominative and the Accusative, the second declension endings for the Instrumental, and the third declension endings for the Genitive, the Dative, and the Prepositional. Путь uses the third declension endings for all cases except the Accusative, for which it uses the second declension ending.

In Russian, as in English, many words have been borrowed from other languages. These words do not change their case endings to reflect their use in a sentence. However, adjectives modifying them reflect the correct case, number and gender. These nouns can be masculine, feminine or neuter.

The concept of case is essential to the understanding of Russian grammar. In English, word order determines whether a noun is a subject, direct object, indirect object or object of a preposition. In Russian, the role of any noun in a sentence is apparent by its case.
There are six main cases in Russian that apply to adjectives, nouns, and pronouns. The six cases tell how a word is being used in a sentence. These are presented below with their basic meanings.

td.p: used for the subject of a sentence
used for the direct object of most verbs; the object of some prepositions
used to show possession; absence or negation; the object of some verbs and prepositions
used only with prepositions, often showing location
used for indirect objects, often showing to whom something is given, said, or necessary; the object of some verbs and prepositions
used to show the means by which an action is performed; the object of some verbs and prepositions

div.p: Note: The terms prepositional and locative are interchangeable depending on the preferences of the author.
For more complete information on the different cases, see:

The nominative case is the form of nouns, adjectives, pronouns, and numerals given in the dictionary. The basic uses of the nominative case in sentences are as follows.
1. The nominative case is used to denote the grammatical subject of a sentence. It is used in the predicate with linking verbs, especially in the present tense.
Девочка читает. (The girl is reading.)
2. It is used in the predicate with linking verbs, especially in the present tense.
Москва -- большой город. (Moscow is a big city.)
For a comparison of the use of the nominative and the instrumental in the predicate, see:

3. The nominative case is used with the pronoun это (this is) and with the particle вот (here is). Note that there is no agreement in gender and number between вот and это and the noun in the sentence.
Это моя сестра. (This is my sister.)
Это был наш брат. (It was our brother.)
Вот моя деревня, вот мой дом родной. (Here is my village and here is my home.)

4. The nominative is used in expressions of possession with у + genitive. In these constructions, the logical object, thing which is possessed, is in the nominative case, because it is the grammatical subject of a sentence.
У него есть брат. (He has a brother.)
У меня есть детская книга. (I have a children’s book.)
Меня is the genitive of the pronoun я and the logical object, книга, is in the nominative.
5. The nominative case is also used in comparative constructions with как (as) and чем (than).
Я был старше, чем моя сестра. (моя сестра is in the nominative.)
(I was older than my sister.)
Я был такой же глупый, как он. (он is in nominative.)
(I was as stupid as he (was).)

1. The main use of the accusative case is to denote the direct object of transitive verbs:
Он любит Машу. (He loves Masha.)
Он читает книгу. (He is reading a book.)
See also:
2. The accusative case is used with prepositions and specifically, with prepositions following the verbs of motion. See:
3. The accusative case is used to denote a period of time:
Он спал весь день. (He slept all day.)
Я читала всю ночь. (I read all night.)

4. While the genitive is usually used after negated verbs, there are specific uses for the accusative case following negated verbs. The accusative case is used with negated verbs when the negated object is specific, or known:
Он не любит Машу. (He does not love Mary.)
The existence of Mary, a specific person, is not a question.
Compare:
Он не читает книги. (He is not reading a/any book.)
No specific object is implied.
Он не читает книгу. (He is not reading the book.)
A specific book is implied with the accusative object.

1. The genitive case is used to express the relationship between nouns. It corresponds to:
the English of:
чувство долга (sense of duty)
начало урока (the beginning of the lesson)
цвет картины (the color of the picture)
цена книги (the price of the book)
улицы города (the streets of the city)
страницы книги (the pages of the book)
the possessive of the noun:
дом родителей (the parents' house)
сад соседа (the neighbor's garden)
брат жены (the wife's brother)
a part of the whole:
стакан воды (a glass of water)
кусок торта (a piece of cake)
This partitive meaning is related to the English 'some' and 'any':
Я выпил воды.[genitive] (I drank some water.)
as opposed to
Я выпил воду. [accusative] (I drank (all of) the water.)
Я дал ему хлеба. [genitive] (I gave him some bread.)
as opposed to
Я дал ему хлеб. [accusative] (I gave him the bread.)
2. The genitive identifies the second item in a comparison when the comparison is formed without чем:
Я старше брата. (I am older than (my) brother.)
Озеро ближе бассейна. (The lake is closer than the pool.)
Negative Constructions
3. The genitive is used in negative constructions:
нет (there is no) снега, дома, еды (snow, house, food)
не было (there was no) снега, дома, еды (snow, house, food)
не будет (there will be no) снега, дома, еды (snow, house, food)
не видно (there is no sight of ) снега, дома, еды (snow, house, food)
не слышно (there is no sound of) шума, песни (noise, song)
не заметно (you cannot see) снега, дома (snow, house)
Note: The genitive is used in negated sentences, often when the non-existence of the noun is implied. The accusative case may be used when the existence of the object is known. Compare the sentences:
У меня нет денег. (I don't have any money.) [negated object in genitive]
Я не видел фильм. (I didn't see the movie.) [negated object in accusative]

Nouns in the prepositional case are used only with prepositions:
Он говорит о матери. (He is talking about his mother.)
Книга лежит на столе. (The book is on the table.)
Она думает о детях. (She is thinking of the children.)
Маша пишет рассказ о своей бабушке. (Mary is writing a story about her grandmother.)
Note: The prepositional case is alternatively referred to as the locative case.

The main use of the dative case is to denote the indirect object of a verb, i.e., the person for whom the action is performed, the recipient or the beneficiary. Some verbs require an indirect object because of their meaning:
Он дал матери письмо. (He gave the letter to his mother.)
Матери is in the dative case. It is the indirect object.
Письмо is in the accusative case. It is the direct object.
Он рассказал матери новости. (He told the news to his mother.)
Матери is in the dative case. It is the indirect object.
Новости is in the accusative case. It is the direct object.
Он не послал матери подарка. (He didn't send his mother a present.)
Матери is in the dative case. It is the indirect object.
Подарка is in the accusative case. It is the direct object.
Another common use of the dative case is in impersonal constructions such as:
Мне холодно. (I am cold. Literally: It is cold to me.)
Что тебе надо? (What do you need? Literally: What is needed for you?)

The instrumental case denotes the "instrument" or agent of an action. In English, the same meaning is often conveyed with prepositional phrases with 'with' or 'in':
писать карандашом (to write with a pencil)
резать ножом (to cut with a knife)
мыться водой и мылом (to wash with water and soap)
бросать камнями (to throw stones)
дышать кислородом (to breathe oxygen)
говорить низким голосом (to speak in a low voice)
Он писал мелом на доске. (He wrote on the blackboard with chalk.)
Он резал ножом торт. (He cut the cake with a knife.)
2. The instrumental case is also used in the predicate to indicate a temporary or a hypothetical condition in the past or future tense:
Он был рабочим.
(He was a laborer.)
(To become an enemy)

Note: The nominative can be used to express a permanent condition in the past or future with the verb быть (to be). The nominative case is always used in the present tense when быть (to be) is omitted:
Он учитель.
(He is a teacher.)
3. The instrumental is used in constructions expressing the movement of parts of the body:
кивать головой (to nod one's head)
топать ногами (to stamp one's feet)
двигать рукой (to move one's arm)
The same instrumental construction is used for objects held by hands:
хлопать дверью (to slam the door)
4. The instrumental case is used with verbs in the passive voice to denote the one who is performing an action (it corresponds to the English use of the preposition 'by'):
Дом был построен рабочими.
(The house was built by the construction workers.)
The instrumental can also mean "with":
наполнить водой (to fill with water)
кормить мясом (to feed with meat)

The vocative case was used in Old Russian as the form of address. Endings in -о, -е, -и marked the vocative:
Жено! (Oh, my wife), from жена (wife)
Сыне! (Oh, my son) from сын (son)
In modern Russian the nominative case is used for addressing people and only rudimentary forms of the vocative are preserved:
Господи, and Боже ! (My God), from Господь, and Бог

A verb expresses an action or a state of being or condition in a sentence:
Он подарил жене подарок. (He gave his wife a present.)
Наш дом был построен два года назад.
(Our house was built twenty years ago.)
Дети кажутся довольными сегодня. (The children seem happy today.)
На вашем месте я бы написал ему письмо.
(If I were you, I would write him a letter.)
Откроете ли вы мне дверь? (Will you open the door for me?)
A variety of factors affects verb usage and determines the meaning of verbs. For example:
The infinitive of a verb expresses the verb's basic form:
любить (to love)
смотреть (to look)
петь (to sing)

See:
Infinitives
Basic Verb Forms
Russian verbs can appear in one of the three verb moods: indicative, conditional (also called subjunctive), and imperative. Moods express differences in the speaker's or the writer's intent.
The indicative mood indicates the agent of the action that takes place in a sentence, and therefore varies from the basic form by showing the tense, number, and sometimes gender of the agent:
Я любил. (I loved.)
Он смотрит. (He looks.)
Они пели. (They sang.)
The conditional or subjunctive mood expresses action in a hypothetical situation:
Если я не отдохну, то я усну за руллм. (If I don't get some rest, I'll fall asleep behind the wheel.)
The imperative mood is most often used to suggest an action:
Убери свою комнату! (Clean your room!)

See
Mood
There are four verb tenses in Russian: the present tense, the past tense, and two types of future tenses - imperfective and perfective.

See
Verb Tenses

All Russian verbs are either perfective or imperfective. The imperfective aspect views the action as something in progress. The perfective aspect views the action as a result of something either completed or to be completed at some moment of past or future time.

See
Aspect
Verb Formation
Perfective Imperfective Formation Prefixes
Perfective Imperfective Formation Suffixes

All verbs in Russian change their endings to reflect the agent of the action. These conjugations fall into two main categories- first and second conjugation. Verbs that are conjugated according to one of these patterns are called regular verbs. As in any language, there are certain exceptions to the rules governing verbs. For examples of irregular verb conjugations, please refer to the appropriate section.

See
Regular Verbs
First Conjugation Verbs
First Conjugation Verbs with Stem Changes
First Conjugation Verbs with Consonant Mutation
Second Conjugation Verbs
Second Conjugation Verbs with Consonant Mutation
Irregular Verbs
Three other important classifications of verbs include: transitive and intransitive verbs (divided according to whether a verb can and cannot have an object), reflexive verbs (which end in -ся), and modal verbs (which are usually used with an infinitive).
Transitive and Intransitive Verbs
Reflexive Verbs
Modal Verbs
Specific types of verbal constructions include:

Verbs serve as the basis for other forms of speech, such as participles (parts of speech which possess qualities of both verbs and adjectives) and gerunds (verb forms which describe secondary actions):
verb: летать (to fly) - participle: летающий (flying) - gerund: летая (while flying).

See also:
Verbs Governing the Dative

The basic verb forms in Russian are as follows:

td.p: Нужно любить. (It is nessessary to love.)
Он всегда любил яблоки. (He always loved apples.)
Дети будут любить музыку. (The children will love music.)
Человек, любящий книги. (A person who loves books.)
Учитель, любимый всеми. (A teacher beloved by all.)
Старичок, любивший танцевать. (A little old man who loved to dance.)
Дом, постролнный Давидом. (The house built by David.)
Любя его, она не могла его предать. (Loving him, she could not betray him.)

div.p: Most verb conjugations are categorizes as first and second conjugation. For information on these conjugation patterns, see Regular Verbs.
For the conjugations of the most common irregular verbs, see the Appendix of Irregular Verbs.

Every verb in Russian has an aspect, either imperfective or perfective.
An imperfective verb refers to a repeated action or denotes the process of an action or a state without any reference to its completion:
Я пишу письмо. (I am writing a letter).
Я всегда пишу письма по-русски. (I always write letters in Russian).
Я писал письмо. (I was writing a letter).
Я буду писать письмо. (I will be writing a letter).
Imperfective verbs have three tenses:

td.p: я буду писать (I will be writing)

div.p: A perfective verb indicates an action which has been completed in the past or will be completed in the future. It can emphasize the result of an action, its brevity, or its immediacy. Both of the following sentences have a perfective meaning, stressing the completion of action.
Я написал ему письмо. (I wrote him a letter).
Я напишу ему письмо. (I will write him a letter).
Perfective verbs have only two tenses:
Usually, the imperfective form is unprefixed and the perfective form has a prefix which endows it with the perfective meaning, as in the example of the verb писать (to write) in the above sentences:
писать (to write)- imperfective
написать (to write)- perfective

See Perfective Imperfective Formation Prefixes, Perfective Imperfective Formation Suffixes, and Verbs of Motion Prefixes. Also, see Irregular Verbs for information on verbs that do not share the same root for their two aspects.

The most common method of forming the perfective aspect of a verb from the imperfective is by adding a prefix. Some prefixes are considered semantically neutral in that their only impact on a verb is to make it perfective. Other prefixes form the perfective aspect and impart specific meaning as well. It is not uncommon for one prefix to have several meanings. It is also interesting to note that it is the prefixed verbs in Russian that frequently have figurative meaning.
The following prefixes often have semantically neutral meanings. The imperfective verb refers to the process of the action, and the perfective refers to the completion.
Many prefixes clarify the meaning of the time within which the action takes place. The prefixes по- and за-, for example, can denote the beginning of an action:
The prefix по- can also convey the meaning of an action taking place within a limited duration of time:
The prefix за- offers a good example of a prefix that can create many different meanings. Presented below are some of the many meanings associated with this prefix:

td.p: to flood, to pour all over
to run in for a moment (while en route somewhere)

div.p: As seen here, some prefixes give the perfective meaning to a verb and create a specific, new meaning for the verb as well. Some of these verbs then require an imperfective meaning that is different from the original imperfective verb. This is accomplished by means of suffixes.
See Perfective and Imperfective Formation Suffixes.

item.title: The Prefixes of the Verbs of Motion

div.p: Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

p.span: The Prefixes of the Verbs of Motion

div.p: Verbs of motion can be prefixed to express different meanings. Prefixed verbs of motion are usually associated with specific prepositions to fully convey that meaning. The prefixed verb, preposition, and the case of the object of the preposition, define the particular motion associated with the prefixed verb. The following verbs are not all verbs of motion, however, the prefixes can apply the same meaning to any action that implies motion, even figurative motion.

td.p: to walk out of the woods
to walk away from the window
to walk up to the house
to banish, oust from the country

Russian verbs possess three tenses: the present, the past, and two forms of the future tense: the simple future and the compound future. Please refer to one of the topics below for a full discussion.

See Also:
Verbs
Aspect
Subject-Predicate Agreement
Appendix of Irregular Verbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
The present tense exists only for imperfective verbs (see Aspect). Since perfective verbs are used to denote the completion of an action, they logically can have no present tense.
Imperfective verbs in the present tense can refer to an action that is happening at the present moment:
Я читаю книгу. (I am reading a book.)
Or to an action which takes place regularly:
Я читаю каждый вечер. (I read every evening.)
Or to an action which can take place continuously:
Я читаю по-французски. (I read French.)
For the conjugation of 1st and 2nd conjugation verbs in the present tense, see Regular Verbs and Appendix of Irregular Verbs.

See Also:
Verbs
Aspect
Verb Tenses
Past
Future
Subject-Predicate Agreement
Appendix of Irregular Verbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

The past tense is formed by removing the infinitive ending and adding the correct past tense ending to denote that the subject of the verb is masculine (-л), feminine (-ла), neuter(-ло), or plural (-ли). For example:
infinitive (imperfective) - masculine, feminine, neuter, plural
делать - делал, делала, делало, делали

The past tense is formed from both imperfective and perfective verbs with the general difference in meaning of 'an action was performed in the past' for imperfective verbs and 'an action was completed in the past.' for perfective ones.
See Regular Verbs and Appendix of Irregular Verbs.

Appendix of Irregular Verbs

The future tense of a perfective verb (also called "the simple future tense") is formed by following the present tense conjugation. Compare the present imperfective and future perfective forms:
Я делаю 'I am making/doing' or 'I make/do'
Я сделаю'I will make/do' with the emphasis on the completion of the action
Future Tense: Imperfective
The future tense of an imperfective verb (also called "the compound future tense) is formed with the addition of the future form of the verb, быть 'to be', plus the imperfective infinitive.
infinitive - 1st, 2nd, 3rd person singular, 1st, 2nd, 3rd person plural
быть - буду, будешь, будет будем, будете, будут.
Я делаю. (I am making/doing or I make/do)
Я буду делать. (I will do or I will be doing)

See Also:
Verbs
Aspect
Verb Tenses
Present
Past
Subject-Predicate Agreement
Appendix of Irregular Verbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Russian verbs are divided into two broad categories referred to as first conjugation and second conjugation.
First conjugation verbs can be recognized by the -ешь/-лшь ending in the present (or perfective future) tense of the second person singular and the -ут/-ют ending in the third person plural.
div.a: First Conjugation Verbs with Stem Changes
First Conjugation Verbs with Consonant Mutation
div.p: Second conjugation verbs can be identified by the -ишь ending in the present (or perfective future) tense of the second person singular and the -ат/-ят ending in the third person plural.
div.a: Second Conjugation Verbs with Consonant Mutation
div.p: Irregular verbs often combine characteristics of both conjugation types. For information on the conjugation of irregular verbs, see Irregular Verbs.

See Also:
Verbs
Aspect
Perfective Imperfective Formation Prefixes
Perfective Imperfective Formation Suffixes
Verb Tenses
Appendix of Irregular Verbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
A majority of Russian verbs fall into the category of First Conjugation. To some extent, these verbs can be recognized by the infinitive ending, including:
verbs ending in -ать (4 exclusions)
verbs ending in -еть
verbs ending in -ять verbs (a few exclusions)
all other verbs

The following conjugation patterns are representative of First Conjugation verbs with no consonant or vowel changes made to the verb stem. The ending -ть, -ти is dropped and the personal ending is added.
Читать (imperfective, to read); -ать infinitive ending; stress remains on syllable before personal ending
Вынести (perfective, to carry/take [something] out); -сти -зти, -зть infinitive endings, (Note that as in this example, the prefix вы- often takes the stress):
Болеть (imperfective, to be sick/ill with); -еть infinitive ending; stress remains on syllable before personal ending:
Гулять (imperfective, to take a walk); -ять infinitive ending; stress remains on syllable before personal ending:
Вернуться (perfective, to return/come back [reflexive verb]); -нуть infinitive ending (always first conjugation); in this example, stress remains on the personal ending throughout:
See First Conjugation Verbs with Stem Changes and First Conjugation Verbs with Consonant Mutation.

See Also:
Verbs

item.title: First Conjugation Verbs with Stem Changes

div.p: Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

p.span: First Conjugation Verbs with Stem Changes

div.p: A second category of First Conjugation Verbs includes those that have vowel changes before the personal ending is added to the stem. The following conjugations are representative of these changes.
Чувствовать (imperfective, to feel/sense); -овать infinitive ending with -ова replaced by -у-. Verb stems ending in ж, ш, ч, щ, ц are followed by -евать due to the spelling rule for these consonants.

Note: This category includes a subset of verbs of foreign origin that show no distinction between the imperfective and perfective aspect, such as: атаковать (to attack), гарантировать (to guarantee), финансировать (to finance).
Мыть (imperfective, to wash [something]); -ыть infinitive ending; -ы- replaced by -о-; stress remains on syllable before personal ending
Пить (imperfective, to drink); one syllable infinitive with -ить ending; -и- replaced by -ь- . Imperative is formed with -е- (пей/пейте)
Клевать (imperfective, to peck/pick); -евать infinitive ending; -ева- replaced by -ю-. Stress on personal ending.
Понять (perfective, to understand/comprehend); -нять infinitive ending; -ня- replaced by -йм-. Also, the verb, снять (to take down, remove) replaces the -ня- with -им-
See First Conjugation Verbs and First Conjugation Verbs with Consonant Mutation.

item.title: First Conjugation Verbs with Consonant Mutation

div.p: Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

p.span: First Conjugation Verbs with Consonant Mutation

div.p: Some First Conjugation verbs experience certain changes to the final stem consonant. These changes are as follows:
1. in verbs ending in -ать,-л- is inserted after stems ending in б, в, м, п, ф
Трепать (imperfective, to pull about/tumble/tousle)
2. in verbs ending in -ать:
stems ending in г, д, з change to ж
stems ending in к, т change to ч
stems ending in х, с change to ш
stems ending in ск, ст change to щ
Сказать (perfective, to say, speak)
3. in verbs ending in -чь, stems ending in ч change to к in first person singular and third person plural; or to г in first person singular and third person plural and ж in the other persons.
Мочь (imperfective, to be able)
4. in verbs ending in -сти, -сть, с changes to д
Вести (imperfective, to lead)
See First Conjugation Verbs and First Conjugation Verbs with Stem Changes.

See Also:
Verbs
Aspect
Perfective Imperfective Formation Prefixes
Perfective Imperfective Formation Suffixes
Regular Verbs
Verb Tenses
Appendix of Irregular Verbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Second Conjugation verbs include the following:
- Most verbs ending in -ить
- Seven verbs ending in -еть : смотреть, видеть, терпеть, вертеть, зависеть, ненавидеть, обидеть
- Four verbs ending in -ать: слышать, дышать, гнать, держать
- A few verbs ending in -ять

The following conjugations are representative of Second Conjugation verbs that have no consonant changes made to the infinitive stem. The infinitive ending is removed and the stem ends in a consonant.
Говорить (imperfective, to speak/talk); stress on personal ending throughout
Держать (imperfective, to keep/hold); stems ending in ж, ш, ч, щ are followed by -у in the first person singular and -ат in the third person plural
Смотреть (imperfective, to look/look at)
Положить (imperfective, to put, lay); stems ending in ж, ш, ч, щ are followed by -у in the first person singular and -ат in the third person plural
See Second Conjugation Verbs with Consonant Mutation.

See Also:

item.title: Second Conjugation Verbs with Consonant Mutation

div.p: Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

p.span: Second Conjugation Verbs with Consonant Mutation

div.p: Some Second Conjugation verbs experience certain changes to the final stem consonant. These changes are as follows:
1. in verbs ending in -ить, -еть,-л- is inserted after stems ending in б, в, м, п, ф in the first person singular form
Любить (imperfective, to love/like)
Терпеть (imperfective, to suffer/endure)
2. in verbs ending in -ить, -еть:
stems ending in г, д, з change to ж in the first person singular form
stems ending in к, т change to ч in the first person singular form
stems ending in х, с change to ш in the first person singular form
stems ending in ск, ст change to щ in the first person singular form
Ходить (imperfective indefinite, to go/walk/move)
Видеть (imperfective , to see)

An important spelling rule to remember when conjugating verbs of the second conjugation dictates that after the letters ж, ч, ш, щ the first person singular ends in у rather than ю, and the third person plural ends in -ат rather than -ят:
держать (to hold)- 1st. person singular: держу 3rd. person plural: держат.
See Second Conjugation Verbs.

See Also:
Verbs
Aspect
Perfective Imperfective Formation Prefixes
Perfective Imperfective Formation Suffixes
Regular Verbs
Verb Tenses

Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

There are three distinct verb moods in Russian: the Indicative, the Subjunctive or Conditional, and the Imperative. Please see the following sections for a full explanation of the usage and of the formation of each of these moods.

See Also:
Verbs
Aspect
Verb Tenses
Appendix of Irregular Verbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

The Indicative mood is used to express statements and ask questions. The indicative cannot express commands (imperative mood) or hypothetical, supposed conditions or actions (subjunctive mood). Verbs in the indicative mood have a present tense, a past tense, and two future tenses (the simple future and the compound future). Indicative verbs can also be perfective or imperfective, and can have either an active or a passive voice.
Малыши любят играть в прятки.
(Kids like to play hide-and-seek.)
Вчера ребята играли в футбол.
(Yesterday children played football.)
Можно взять твою ручку?
(Can I take your pen?)

See Also:
Verbs
Mood
Imperative Mood
Subjunctive or Conditional Mood
Aspect
Verb Tenses
Questions
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Verbs in the imperative mood are used for commands, requests, and instructions. The imperative mood is formed from the third person plural of the imperfective present or perfective future verb forms. To form an imperative verb, drop the -ат/-ят or the -ут/-ют ending, and substitute the letter -й, -и, or -ь for a familiar address, or the ending -ите, -йте, or -ьте for the formal singular/plural address.
Note that the endings -й, -йте are used when the stem of the verb ends in a vowel, while the endings -и, -ите form the imperative for verbs with stems ending in a consonant.
Reflexive verbs always retain their characteristic -ся/-сь ending in the imperative mood.
Imperfective Imperative:
Perfective Imperative:
Apart from issuing commands or making suggestions, the imperative mood can also be used to express an invitation to participate in a joint action. This invitation can be made in two ways:
The future tense of a perfective verb in the second person plural form can be used without the pronoun мы (we) to suggest joint action:
Пойдлмте на прогулку после обеда. (Let's go for a walk after dinner.)
Забудем о нашей ссоре. (Let's forget about our fight.)
Note the ending -те in the first example- it is frequently added to imperative verbs which are meant to address more than one person, or to address one person in a polite, formal way.

Another way to invite participation is by the use of the verb давать in its imperative form, давай/давайте (let's), placed before the verb describing the suggested action. The verb can be in the first person plural or infinitive form of either imperfective or perfective verbs:
Давай пойдлм в музей. (Let's go to the museum.)
Давайте упражняться. (Let's exercise.)

See Also:
Verbs
Mood
Indicative Mood
Subjunctive or Conditional Mood
Verb Tenses
Aspect
Negatives
Imperative Sentences
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

In contrast to the indicative mood, the subjunctive, or conditional, verb mood denotes action which is supposed or uncertain rather than actual. The particle бы, sometimes shortened to б, can always be found in a sentence with a conditional verb, which will usually appear in the past tense.
Eсли бы погода была хорошая, я поехала бы завтра на море.
(If the weather is good, I'd go to the seashore tomorrow.)
The particle бы/б normally follows the verb, but it is grammatically correct to put it in other positions within a sentence. However, бы never comes first in the sentence:
Я с удовольствием погулял бы в саду. (I'd be delighted to walk in the garden.)
Я бы с удовольствием погулял в саду. (I'd be delighted to walk in the garden.)

The subjunctive mood can be used to convey fear that something undesirable might happen. When expressing apprehension, the sentence containing the conditional verb will also contain the negative particle не:
Не ходила бы ты одна ночью. (You shouldn't walk alone at night.)
Не поскользнулся бы он на льду. (I hope he doesn't slip on the ice.)
Не уволили бы ел с работы. (I hope she doesn't get fired from work.)
Uses of Conjunction Чтобы
The subjunctive mood can also be used with the verbs expressing a wish, a command, a request, or purpose.
In such cases the particle бы/б becomes incorporated into the conjunction чтобы.
Она хочет, чтобы ты помыл посуду.
(She wants you to wash the dishes.)
Мама попросила, чтобы мы позвонили ей во вторник.
(Mom asked that we call her on Tuesday.)
Она купила новую машину, чтобы мы смогли поехать в путешествие.
(She bought a new car, so that we could go on a trip.)
Папа рассказал смешную историю, чтобы девочка перестала плакать.
(Dad told a funny story, so that the little girl would stop crying.)

Another common usage of the subjunctive, or conditional mood in Russian is the sentence construction that includes the articles бы and ни in the same sentence to convey the meaning of " whatever", "whoever", "whenever", and "however":
Как бы я ни спешила, я всл равно опоздаю.
(No matter how much I hurry, I'll be late anyway.)
Кто бы ни позвонил, меня нет дома.
(No matter who calls, I am not home.)
Что бы он ни говорил, она не изменяла свол решение.
(No matter what he said, she still didn't change her mind.)
Когда бы я ни приходила, они всегда ссорились.
(No matter when I came over, they were always fighting.)

See Also:
Verbs
Mood
Indicative Mood
Imperative Mood
Verb Tenses
Negatives
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Russian uses the particle не placed immediately before the verb to form negative verbs:
Он не опоздал. (He was not late.)
Я не люблю кино. (I don't like movies.)
Вы не знаете ел? (Don't you know her?)

When a negative pronoun is the subject or the object of a negated sentence, не is still used, creating a double negative. While double negatives are avoided in English, they are required in Russian with negative pronouns and some negative adverbs.
Он ничего не знает. (He doesn't know anything).
Я никого не боюсь. (I am not afraid of anyone.)
Она не любит никакую музыку. (She doesn't like any kind of music.)

The particle нет can function as a verb in Russian, and some linguists identify its origin as the contraction of the particle не and the verb есть, present tense third person singular of the verb быть (to be). When used in constructions with the object in the genitive case, нет can mean "(there) is not/are not; (there) is no/are no; don't/doesn't have: "
Мамы нет дома. (Mom isn't home.)
Работы нет. (There is no work.)
У него нет времени. (He doesn't have time.)

See Also:
Verbs
Genitive
Sentences
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

There are relatively few Russian verbs that could be absolutely described as regular, that is, belonging strictly to the first or second conjugation pattern. Instead, there are many variations to these patterns. They include different verb endings, consonant and vowel substitutions, and other changes that form standard variations under the umbrella definitions of first and second conjugation. These verb conjugations are discussed in Regular Verbs.

There are, however, several verbs that don't follow any of these variations or combine characteristics of the two conjugation types. These include the verb быть, 'to be' and others. For complete information on their conjugation patterns see:
Appendix of Irregular Verbs.
Besides the present tense conjugation, there are other features of verbs which can be considered irregular.
Irregularities in Aspect

All Russian verbs can be classified by their aspect, perfective or imperfective. (See Aspect.) Most verbs change from one aspect to the other by means of prefix or suffix changes. In this way, it is usually possible to recognize a perfective/imperfective verb pair. However, some verbs do not share the same root for their two aspects. Included in this category are:

* The unprefixed form, ходить, has no perfective form. It is the indeterminate form of the verb, 'to go.' Идти is the determinate form of the verb. Both ходить and идти have their own perfective forms.
Some verbs are not part of an aspectual pair This can be due to the logical meaning of the verb.
Быть, жить - imperfective only. It is not possible 'to be' or 'to live' with a perfective meaning. These verbs always refer to the process not the completion of the action.
Принадлежать, зависеть, значить - 'to belong,' 'to depend,' 'to mean.' Again, these verbs denote a constant condition that can have no logical perfective meaning.

Грянуть, заблудиться, 'to burst out (with sound and figuratively),' 'to lose one's way.' These verbs have only a perfective form because their meaning is inherently instantaneous or signifies only the onset, or the result of an action.

Verbs ending in -ировать - телеграфировать, коллективизировать, гармонизировать, (to telegraph, to collectivize, to harmonize) all have one form for perfective and imperfective. They are usually verbs created from borrowed words. Their aspect must be determined from the context of the sentence.
Irregularities in Usage

Some verbs lack standard verb forms because of their meaning. For instance, the verbs видеть and слышать, 'to see, to hear,' have no imperative form. As in English, the imperative is Look! and Listen! from the verbs слушать, смотреть.

Some verbs lack a first or second person conjugation because their meaning excludes action by a person. For instance, значить, звучать, 'to mean,' 'to sound,' are used only in the third person. Other expressions are used to express the meaning, 'I mean, you mean,' 'I sound, you sound.'
Commonly used irregular verbs are conjugated in the Appendix of Irregular Verbs.

See Also:
Verbs
Aspect
Perfective Imperfective Formation Prefixes
Perfective Imperfective Formation Suffixes
Verb Tenses
Appendix of Irregular Verbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
If the grammatical and logical subject of the sentence denotes the person or thing performing action, the verb is in the active voice:
Плтр построил дом. (Peter built the house.)
Peter is the subject of this sentence. He performed the action: построил дом (built the house). So, the verb построил (built) is in the active voice.
If the subject of the sentence denotes the receiver of the action, the verb is in the passive voice:
Дом был построен Петром. (The house was built by Peter.)
The subject of the sentence, дом (the house), is the "receiver" of the action. The agent Плтр (Peter) is the indirect object, while был построен (was built) is in the passive voice.

The object of the sentence in the active voice becomes the subject of the sentence with the passive voice. The indirect object in the sentence with passive voice is always put in the instrumental case. For example:
Compare:

td.p: Полицейский открыл дверь. (The policeman opened the door.)
Дверь была открыта полицейским. (The door was opened by the policeman.)
Кто-то убрал комнату. (Somebody cleaned the room.)
Комната была убрана кем-то. (The room was cleaned.)
Толстой написал "Войну и мир". (Tolstoy wrote War and Peace.)
"Война и мир" написана Толстым. (War and Peace was written by Tolstoy.)

div.p: The passive voice is used frequently both in spoken and in literary Russian. The passive voice can be expressed with short forms of passive participles and the verb быть (to be). Note that in the present tense, the verb быть (to be) is omitted:
Present tense:
Мой папа любим всеми его учениками.
(My dad is loved by all his students.)
Past tense:
Мой папа был любим всеми его учениками.
(My dad was loved by all his students.)
Future tense:
Мой папа будет любим всеми его учениками.
(My dad will be loved by all his students.)

See Also:
Verbs
Aspect
Verb Tenses
Participles
Subject-Predicate Agreement
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Transitive verbs require an object to complete their meaning, and express that action which is carried from the subject to the object. Transitive verbs take a direct object in the accusative case without a preposition, and can answer the question "whom/what?"
Intransitive verbs are those which do not require an object to complete their meaning, and therefore do not have a direct object. Intransitive verbs are frequently accompanied by prepositions:
Please note that reflexive verbs do not take a direct object in the accusative case. They can be followed by prepositional phrases to indicate an object:

td.p: (to fall in love with a girl)

div.p:
See Also:
Verbs
Aspect
Verb Tenses
Subject-Predicate Agreement
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

As a rule, the main function of reflexive verbs in a sentence is to show that the agent of the action and the receiver (or object) of that action are the same person/thing. Reflexive verbs are formed by the addition of the ending -ся (a contraction of the pronoun себя (oneself)) to the infinitive form, as well as to some of the other verb forms:
Бабушка моет посуду. (Grandmother is washing the dishes.)- not reflexive.
Кошка моется. (The cat is washing itself.)- the verb моется here is reflexive.
Some reflexive verbs show reciprocal action:
целоваться (to kiss)
обниматься (to hug)
драться (to fight)
There are some verbs ending in -ся which show neither a reflexive, nor a reciprocal action, but express a quality or a characteristic:
Собаки кусаются. (Dogs bite.)
Планета вращается. (The planet revolves/spins.)
Reflexive verbs can also express an action's result:
Я выспался. (I slept well.)
Она расплакалась.(She burst into tears.)
Они заблудились (They got lost.)
Some reflexive verbs do not possess a non-reflexive form. Some of the most frequently used of these are:

Reflexive verbs conjugate in the same patterns as regular verbs, but the reflexive ending is always added. The following is a table showing the conjugation patterns of reflexive verbs in the present tense. Note that when a verb form ends in a vowel, the reflexive ending -ся is changed to the reflexive ending -сь.

See Also:
Verbs
Verb Tenses
Aspect
Reflexive Pronouns
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Impersonal verbs are those which occur in sentences without a logical subject. They express actions which can happen without the aid of any person or thing. Impersonal verbs can appear in the third person singular for the present and future tenses, in neuter singular for the past tense, or in the third person plural, depending on the type of impersonal construction.
Constructions with the 3rd Person Singular
A large category of impersonal constructions describes events happening in nature:

td.p: It is/ was/ will be draughty
It is/ was/ will be getting light
It is/ was/ will be getting dark

div.p: Another large category of impersonal constructions describes moods or physical states of animate beings. As a rule, the logical subject of such constructions will be in the dative case, although a small group of impersonal verbs will have the subject in the accusative case.
Examples of impersonal constructions with the dative case:
Ему везлт. (He is lucky.)
Мне хочется мороженого. (I want some ice cream.)
Николаю всю ночь не спалось. (Nicholas couldn't sleep all night.)
Собаке показалось, что кто-то проникнул в дом.
(It seemed to the dog that someone had gotten inside the house.)
Examples of impersonal constructions with the accusative case:
Нас тошнило в лодке. (We were nauseous on the boat.)
Таню знобит. (Tanya is feverish.)
Костю лихорадит. (Kostya is feverish.)
Constructions with the 3rd Person Plural
A type of frequently used impersonal constructions in Russian uses the third person plural (they) without identifying who "they" is:
Меня зовут Юлия. ((They/people)call me Julia.)
Говорят, что Одесса -самый весллый город.
((They/people)say that Odessa is the most fun-loving city.)

See Also:
Verbs
Verb Tenses
Dative with Impersonal Constructions
Predicative Adverbs
Subject-Predicate Agreement
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Impersonal constructions in Russian often require use of the dative case for the logical subject. There are several words which are commonly used in these constructions. These words are often referred to as "impersonal predicates."
Ему надо было учиться.
(He had to study.)
Мне было холодно всю ночь.
(I was cold all night.)

See Also:
Verbs
Verb Tenses
Impersonal Verbs
Predicative Adverbs
Dative
Subject-Predicate Agreement

Some frequently used constructions in Russian require a combination of a verb and a preposition, with the associated noun put in a specific case. The most common prepositions used in such constructions are:
в (in), за (for, about), на (on), к (to), над (over), по (along).
в + accusative:
в + prepositional:
за + accusative:
за + instrumental:
на + accusative:
на + prepositional:
к + dative:
над + instrumental:

td.p: (to play a joke on one's wife)

div.p: по + dative:
