Verbs Governing the Genitive
Verbs Governing the Dative
Verbs Governing the Instrumental
Verbs Followed by the Infinitive
Verbs
Verb Tenses
Aspect
Subject-Predicate Agreement
Appendix of Irregular Verbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Some of the most frequently used verbs that require the object in the genitive case:
Я боюсь темноты. (I am afraid of the dark.)
Он лишился друга. (He lost a friend.)
Эти проблемы меня не касаются. (These problems don't concern me.)
Армия добилась победы. (The army attained victory.)
Я стесняюсь своей полноты. (I am embarrassed by my plumpness.)
Additionally, the genitive always follows the following verbs:
Нам недосталт денег. (We don't have enough money.)
Когда гуляете ночью, опасайтесь хулиганов. (When walking at night, beware of thugs.)

See Also:
Verbs
Verb Tenses
Genitive
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Some verbs are used with an indirect object in the dative case. They denote giving assistance or performing a service, or, conversely, this construction can be used to express actions which prevent, or hinder action:
Three additional verbs denoting assistance/hindrance take the object in the dative case:
Он аккомпанировал ученику на пианино.
(He accompanied his student on the piano).
Он запретил ученику разговаривать.
(He forbade his student to talk).
Он помогал ученику играть.
(He was helping his student to play).
Verbs which take the indirect object in the dative case can also denote attitude :
Он верил матери. (He believed his mother.)
Он доверял учителю. (He trusted his teacher.)
Мать радовалась моим успехам. (My mother was happy with my success.)
Я удивляюсь вашему поведению. (I am surprised at your behavior.)

See Also:
Verbs
Verb Tenses
Dative
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Verbs which take the object in the instrumental case can denote use or control:
Он владел всем лесом. (He owned the entire woods.)
Он правил страной десять лет. (He governed the country for ten years).
Verbs that require an instrumental case can also denote attitude:
Он восхищался музыкой. (He was awed by the music.)
Она дорожила своим кольцом. (She valued (treasured) her ring.)
Он любовался детьми. (He gazed at his children lovingly.)

See Also:
Verbs
Verb Tenses
Instrumental
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Grammar books about the Russian language do not describe what are called modal verbs in English (can, may, should) separately from other Russian verbs.
A couple of the most frequently used ones are:
мочь (to be able to)
хотеть (to want)
Я могу написать ему письмо. (I can write a letter to him.)
Я хочу, чтобы ты написал письмо по-русски. (I want you to write a letter in Russian.)
These verbs are conjugated irregularly.
Some English modal verbs correspond in Russian to impersonal constructions with the logical subject in the dative case.

See Also:
Verbs
Verb Tenses
Impersonal Constructions with Dative Case
Appendix of Irregular Verbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Some verbs are used as part of the predicate together with nouns or noun phrases. They are called linking verbs:
становиться / стать (to become)
быть (to be)
делаться / сделаться (to make oneself)

See Also:
Verbs
Verb Tenses
Instrumental Case
Appendix of Irregular Verbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

The infinitive is the basic form of a verb, from the stem of which most other verbal forms are derived (a small number of verbal forms are derived from the stem of the 3rd person plural in the present tense). You can recognize the infinitive form by its ending:
-ать, -ять, -еть, -уть, -оть, -ыть, -чь, -ти, -зть, -сть, -ить.
The infinitive form of reflexive verbs will have one of the above endings with the suffix -ся at the end: мыться (to wash oneself).
The infinitive form has several important uses in Russian:
It is used as the second verb in a sentence when both verbs refer to the same subject:
Наташа любит читать. (Natasha loves to read.)
Солнце перестало светить. (The sun ceased to shine.)
Мы решили уйти. (We decided to leave.)
Дети пошли купаться. (The children went to go swimming.)
The infinitive is always used with the following short form adjectives:
Хороший солдат всегда готов отдать свою жизнь за Родину.
(A good soldier is always ready to give up his life for his Motherland.)
Вы обязаны приходить на работу вовремя.
(You are obligated to arrive to work on time.)
The infinitive is always used with an impersonal predicate. The following table shows some of the most common impersonal predicates:
Note that the logical subject of an impersonal predicate is in the dative case:
Вам необходимо пойти к врачу.
(It is imperative that you go to the doctor.)
Дедушке трудно подниматься по лестнице.
(It is difficult for Grandpa to walk up the stairs.)
The infinitive can be used to express a command:
Не курить! (No smoking!)
Молчать! (Silence!)
When the infinitive is followed by the particle бы, a wish is expressed:
Поспать бы до обеда. (I wish I could nap till dinner.)
Уехать бы в даллкие края. (It would be nice to go away to some distant lands.)
When the infinitive appears between the particles не and ли it expresses indecision:
Не позвонить ли маме? (Maybe I should call my Mom.)
Не купить ли новые занавеси? (Maybe I should buy new curtains.)

See Also:
Verbs
Verbs Followed by the Infinitive
Phrases with Genitive
Basic Verb Forms
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Some Russian verbs are frequently followed by an infinitive. In general, these include two categories of verbs.
1. Verbs denoting the beginning, continuation, or completion of an action:
Он начинал писать письмо. (He started to write a letter.)
Музыка продолжала играть. (The music continued to play.)
Мы кончили играть в шахматы. (We finished playing chess.)
2. Verbs denoting purpose or intent:
Она попыталась услышать их разговор. (She tried to hear their conversation.)
Он хотел читать книгу. (He wanted to read the book).

See Also:
Verbs
Verbs Followed by the Infinitive
Phrases with Genitive
Basic Verb Forms
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Participles are formed from verbs but decline like adjectives. They agree in person, gender and number with the nouns they modify. They have an adjectival use in a sentence, usually translated as an adjectival clause in English. There are both active and passive participles. The active participle describes the agent of an action, while the passive participle describes its recipient, or object.
Present Active Participle
The present active participle is formed by replacing the last letter of the present tense 3rd person plural (-т) with the ending -щий (-щая, -щее, -щие).
3rd person plural - masculine, feminine, neuter, plural:
читают - читающий, читающая, читающее, читающие.
(they) read - one(s) who is (are) reading
бегут - бегущий, бегущая, бегущее, бегущие.
(they) run - one(s) who is (are) running.
плачут - плачущий, плачущая, плачущее, плачущие.
(they) cry - one(s) who is (are) crying.
Past Active Participle
The past active participle is formed by replacing the ending -л from past tense, masculine singular verb and adding the adjectival ending -вший, (-вшая, -вшее, -вшие):
past tense sing. masc. - masculine, feminine, neuter, plural:
читал - читавший, читавшая, читавшее, читавшие.
I, you, he (masc.) read - one(s) who was (were) reading
начал - начавший, начавшая, начавшее, начавшие.
I, you, he (masc.) began - one(s) who was (were) beginning.
играл - игравший, игравшая, игравшее, игравшие.
I, you, he (masc.) played - one(s) who was (were) playing.
Most verbs not ending in -л in the past tense masculine singular, add -ший, (-шая,
-шее, -шие) instead of -вший:
past tense sing. masc.: - masculine, feminine, neuter, plural:
погиб - погибший, погибшая, погибшее, погибшие
I, you, he (masc.) perished - one(s) who has (have) perished.
When past participles are formed from reflexive verbs, they retain the -ся ending:
past tense sing. masc.: - masculine, feminine, neuter, plural:
улыбался - улыбавшийся, улыбавшаяся, улыбавшееся, улыбавшиеся
I, you, he (masc) smiled - one(s) who was (were) smiling
Past Active Participles can be formed from both perfective and imperfective verbs to convey the different meanings of an action completed in the past or covering a span of time in the past.
past tense sing. masc.: - masculine, feminine, neuter, plural:
прочитал - прочитавший, прочитавшая, прочитавшее, прочитавшие
I, you, he (masc.) have read through - one(s) who has (have) read through.
Present Passive Participle

It is important to remember that as a rule, passive participles can only be formed from transitive verbs (verbs whose action is directly aimed at a person or an object).The present passive participle is formed by adding the adjectival ending -ый (-ая, -ое, -ые) to the present tense 1st person plural form of an imperfective verb:
present tense 1st person plural - masculine, feminine, neuter, plural:
любим - любимый, любимая, любимое, любимые
(we) love - one(s) that is (are) loved.
уважаем - уважаемый, уважаемая, уважаемое, уважаемые
(we) respect - one(s) that is (are) respected.
Past Passive Participle
The past passive participles are usually formed from the infinitive by removing -ть анд тчен adding the ending -нный (-нная, -нное, -нные), or the ending -тый (-тая, -тое, -тые).
infinitive - masculine, feminine, neuter, plural:
сделать - сделанный, сделанная, сделанное, сделанные
to make - one(s) that has(have) been made.
мыть - мытый, мытая, мытое, мытые
to wash - one(s) that has (have) been washed.
The past passive participles can have both a long and a short form:
infinitive - Long form: masculine, feminine, neuter, plural:
написать - написанный, написанная, написанное, написанные
to write - that (those) which has (have) been written.
infinitive - Short form: masculine, feminine, neuter, plural:
написать - написан, написана, написано, написаны.
to write - that (those) which has (have) been written.
infinitive - Long form: masculine, feminine, neuter, plural:
одеть - одетый, одетая, одетое, одетые
to dress - that (those) which has (have) been dressed.
infinitive - Short form: masculine, feminine, neuter, plural:
одеть - одет, одета, одето, одеты
to dress - that (those) which has (have) been dressed.

See Also:
Verbs
Gerunds
Participial Clauses
Verb Tenses
Noun-Adjective Agreement
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Gerunds are often called verbal adverbs or adverbial participles. They function as adverbs and are formed from verbs. Gerunds answer the same questions as adverbs do: when, how, and why.
Улыбаясь, она вошла в комнату. (Smiling, she entered the room.)
Солдат шагал, насвистывая весллую мелодию.
(The soldier marched, whistling a merry tune.)
Прочитав письмо, девушка заплакала.
(Having read the letter, the young woman started to cry.)
Like adverbs, gerunds do not possess gender, case, or number. Like verbs, though, gerunds have two aspects: the perfective and the imperfective.
Imperfective Gerunds

Imperfective gerunds, sometimes called present gerunds, express a complementary, or secondary action which is simultaneous with the main verb of the sentence. They are formed from the present tense, third person plural form of verbs by dropping the -ут/-ют or the -ат/-ят ending and adding the -а/-я ending to the stem of the verb. Note that the -а ending is used only when the stem of a verb ends in -ж, -ч, -ш, or -щ.

Occasionally, present gerunds with the endings -учи/-ючи can be found in Russian: идучи (while walking), припеваючи (while singing from joy, splendidly happy). These are mostly archaic, and used in colloquial speech, fairy tales, folk songs, and traditional expressions.
The exception to this rule is the present gerund of the verb быть (to be)- будучи.This gerund is still commonly used in both literary and spoken Russian:
Будучи отличной студенткой, она успешно сдала экзамены.
(Being an excellent student, she successfully passed her exams.)
Present gerunds cannot be formed from all verbs:
Verbs that have an infinitive form ending in -чь or -нуть cannot form present gerunds; for example: мочь (to be able to), жечь (to burn), печь (to bake), гибнуть (to perish).
A few other common verbs incapable of present gerund formation:
Perfective Gerunds
Perfective gerunds, sometimes called past gerunds, express a complementary, or secondary action which has been completed before the action of the main verb takes place:
Прочитав газету, папа позвонил в редакцию.
(Having read the paper, Dad called the editorial department.)
Закончив урок, учительница надела пальто.
(Having finished the lesson, the teacher put on her coat.)

The perfective, or past gerund can be formed from the past tense, masculine singular form of a (usually perfective) verb by dropping the -л ending, and adding the ending -в. The ending -вши appears infrequently.
When the masculine singular in the past tense does not end in -л, the perfective (past) gerund is formed with the ending -ши:
All perfective gerunds formed from reflexive verbs follow the rules described above, and always end with -вшись or (less frequently) -шись, never with -в:

See Also:
Verbs
Participles
Participial Clauses
Verb Tenses
Noun-Adjective Agreement
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
An adjective is a word that is used to modify, supplement, add to, or restrict the meaning of a noun or pronoun. Adjectives typically occur before nouns in a noun phrase or in the predicate:
Прекрасная молодая французская пианистка вошла в элегантный концертный зал.
(The beautiful young French pianist entered the elegant concert hall.)
Вы покупаете красное или зеллное платье?
(Are you buying the red dress or the green one?)
Отцовый кот толстый.
(My father's cat is fat.)
Adjectives answer the following questions:
какой (what kind?):
Какой это зал? Концертный зал.
(What kind of hall is this? A concert hall.)
который (which one?)
Которое платье вы купили? Зеллное платье.
(Which dress did you buy? The green one.)
чей (whose?)
Чей это кот? Отцовый.
(Whose cat is that? My father's.)
See the individual topics for details.

p.a: Sequence of Adjectives in a Noun Phrase

div.p:
See Also:
Abstract Nouns Derived from Adjectives
Forms of the Predicate
Adjective Formation
History of the Russian Language
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
There are three main types of adjectives: descriptive, relative, and possessive.
Descriptive Adjectives
Descriptive adjectives (also called qualitative) usually indicate an inherent quality:
красивый (beautiful), умный (intelligent),
or a physical state, such as age, size and color :
старый (old), большой (large), красный (red).
Relative Adjectives
Relative adjectives express characteristics which cannot vary in degree and which are related to the noun.
каменный пол (stone floor)
химический элемент (chemical element)
As in English, relative adjectives are always placed closest to the noun. For example:
Она упала на холодный каменный пол.
(She fell on the cold stone floor.)
Possessive Adjectives

Possessive adjectives may be formed from nouns with the suffixes -ов, -ев, -ин. These are the only short form adjectives in modern Russian that are fully declinable. They reflect gender, number and case of the modified noun:
отцово наследство (father's heritage)
кошкин дом (cat's house)
мамин брат (mother's brother)
Катина книга (Kathy's book).
A small number of possessive adjectives are formed from names of animals, fish, and birds, using the endings -ий, -ья, -ье, -ьи:
рыбья кость (fish bone)
лисья хитрость (fox's cunning)
беличий хвост (squirrel's tail).
Possessive pronouns in Russian are similar to possessive adjectives in English. For more information, see Possessive Pronouns.

See Also:
Adjectives
Long and Short Adjectives
Comparative and Superlative
Adjective Declension
Sequence of Adjectives in a Noun Phrase
Noun-Adjective Agreement
Forms of the Predicate
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Both long and short form adjectives can be used in the predicate. When a long form adjective is used in the predicate, it indicates a permanent quality of the noun being modified. A short form adjective (when logically possible) in the predicate indicates a temporary quality.
Я увидел прекрасный цветок. (I saw a beautiful flower.)
Цветы прекрасные. (Flowers are beautiful.)
The second example could also use the short form of the adjective:
Эти цветы прекрасны. (These flowers are beautiful.)
Restrictions in Usage of Short form Adjectives

Short form adjectives are used only in the predicate in Russian and only with some tenses of the linking verb for 'to be.' They are not declined and have only four forms: masculine (singular), feminine (singular), neuter (singular), and plural. The following short form adjectives are formed from умный:
Мальчик был умлн. (The boy was clever.)
Девочка была умна. (The girl was clever.)
Это решение было умно. (This decision was clever.)
Дети были умны. (The children were clever.)
Formation of Short form Adjectives

Short form adjectives can be formed from most qualitative adjectives. Since short form adjectives indicate a temporary condition, they are not formed from adjectives which always indicate an inherent condition (e.g., английский -- English). Formation of the short form from the long is illustrated below with the adjectives красивый (beautiful) and похожий (similar):
Short masculine adjectives frequently insert an -о- or a -е- between the consonant at the end of the root and the suffix -н or -к :
краткий- краток (short)
низкий- низок (low)
тонкий- тонок (thin)
смешной- смешон (funny)
е/л is inserted in front of -к while forming a short form adjective if the -к is preceded by one of the following letters: ь, й, ж:
горький- горек (bitter)
стойкий- стоек (strong, durable)
тяжкий- тяжек (severe, grave, serious)
е/л is also inserted in front of -н:
бедный- беден (poor)
больной- болен (sick)
When a long adjective ends in -енный, its short masculine form usually
ends in -ен (ный is dropped):
умеренный- умерен (moderate)
The feminine, neuter, and plural of the short forms keep the -енн :
умеренна, умеренно, умеренны
Two important adjectives have a special short form:
Long form adjective-- Short form (masculine, feminine, neuter, plural)
маленький (little): мал, мала, мало, малы
большой (big): велик, велика, велико, велики
Some short form adjectives have lost their long forms,
for example:
рад (glad): рад, рада, радо, рады.
At times in modern Russian, one can find remnants of short declinable forms of adjectives in some fixed expressions:
среди бела дня (in broad daylight)-
бела дня is genitive of бел (short form of белый) день,
по белу свету (the world over)-
белу свету is dative of бел (short form of белый) свет,
за сине море (beyond the blue sea)-
сине море is accusative of сине (short form of синее) море.

See Also:
Adjectives
Types of Adjectives
Comparative and Superlative Adjectives
Adjective Declension
Sequence of Adjectives in a Noun Phrase
Noun-Adjective Agreement
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Comparative and superlative adjectives are formed from descriptive adjectives, the only type of adjective that can logically vary in degree.
Formation of the Comparative Form
There are two regular methods of forming comparative adjectives: with the suffixes -ее, -ей or with the words более (more), менее (less):
зеллный (green)- зеленее (greener)
весллый (merry)- веселее (merrier)
зеллный (green)- более зеллный (greener)
высокий (tall)- менее высокий (less tall)
Sometimes the prefix по- is added to form the comparative, often with the meaning 'a little':
Мне нужна кровать побольше.
(I need a bigger bed.) (I need a bed that's a little bigger.)
Many adjectives form irregular simple comparative forms. If the stem of a positive adjective ends in г, к, х, д, т, and ст there is a consonant alteration in the comparative form:
дорогой - дороже, (expensive - more expensive)
молодой - моложе, (young - younger)
ллгкий - легче, (light - lighter)
богатый - богаче, (rich - richer)
тихий - тише, (quiet - more quiet)
чистый - чище, (clean - cleaner)
Formation of the Superlative Form
To form the superlative form of adjectives add: -ейший/-айший, ейшая, ейшее or самый + positive adjective:
superlative: masculine, feminine, neuter, plural
бедный (poor) - (poorest) беднейший, беднейшая, беднейшее, беднейшие,
строгий (strict) - (strictest) строжайший, строжайшая, строжайшее, строжайшие.
Prefix наи- is used to express extreme degree with superlative forms:
бедный - наибеднейший,
строгий - наистрожайший.
Constructions with Comparisons
Positive degree:
Он такой же высокий, сильный, знаменитый, как мой брат.
(He is as tall, strong, famous as my brother.)
Она такая же красивая, благородная, дружелюбная, как ел мама.
(She is as beautiful, noble, friendly as her mother.)
Он не такой высокий, сильный, знаменитый, как мой брат.
(He is not as tall, strong, famous as my brother.)
Она не такая красивая, благородная, дружелюбная, как ел мама.
(She is not as beautiful, noble, friendly as her mother.)
Comparative degree:
A comparison may be expressed with the help of the conjunction чем (than)
or with the genitive case used for the second object of comparison:
Он выше, сильнее, чем его брат.
(He is taller, stronger than his brother.)
Он выше, сильнее его брата.
(He is taller, stronger than his brother.)
Superlative Degree:
The superlative degree may be expressed with the aid of qualifiers :
Это самый трудный вопрос грамматики.
(This is the most difficult question in grammar.)
The superlative degree here is expressed with the qualifier грамматики, 'in/of grammar.'
The superlative degree may also be expressed with the aid of a prepositional phrase defining the setting where the comparison is done:
Это самый старый человек в городе.
(This is the oldest man in town.)
В городе, 'in town,' provides the setting for the superlative comparison.
Irregular Comparison
The following adjectives are compared irregularly:
хороший (good)
плохой (bad)
маленький (small)
большой (large)
старый (old)
молодой (young)

These adjectives have a long form comparative that can have either the comparative or the superlative meaning, depending on its use. Four of these adjectives also have a long one-word superlative form.

See Also:
Adjectives
Types of Adjectives
Long and Short Adjectives
Adjective Declension
Sequence of Adjectives in a Noun Phrase
Noun-Adjective Agreement
Coordinate Conjunctions
Comparative and Superlative Adverbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Adjectives are described as having a hard, soft or mixed declension. This distinction is based on the adjectival ending and, sometimes, on the final letter of the root. Both descriptive and relative adjectives follow these three patterns. There are two additional patterns for the relatively small group of possessive adjectives.

Singular adjectives agree in gender, number and case with the noun they modify. Plural adjectives, on the other hand, make no gender distinction. All plural adjectives have the same endings:-ые/-ие, in the nominative plural and one ending for all genders in the oblique cases as well.

It is important to note the animate/inanimate distinction in the accusative case. Adjectives modifying nouns in the accusative case use the genitive ending when the noun refers to an animate being and the nominative ending for inanimate objects.
The Declension of Hard Adjectives
Adjectives are considered hard in Russian when the masculine singular form of an adjective in the nominative case has the -ый or the -ой ending:
белый костюм (white suit, masculine inanimate)
белая книга (white book, feminine inanimate)
белое небо (white sky, neuter)
белые костюмы / книги / небеса (white suits/ books/ skies)
молодой человек (young man, masculine animate).
молодая женщина (young woman, feminine animate)
молодое сердце (young heart, neuter)
молодые люди / женщины / сердца (young men (people)/ women / hearts

td.p: Plural - one ending for Masculine, Feminine and Neuter

div.p: The Declension of Soft Adjectives
In soft adjectives the stem ends in -н, followed by the ending -ий:
синий (blue ), осенний (fall), зимний (winter), нынешний (current), передний (front).
Nominative endings:
синий костюм (blue suit, masculine inanimate)
синяя книга (blue book, feminine inanimate)
синее небо (blue sky, neuter)
синие костюмы / книги / небеса (blue suits/ books/ skies)
The Declension of Mixed Adjectives
Mixed adjectives have both hard and soft endings. They end with either -ий or ой. One of the following letters will always precede the ending of a mixed adjective:
ж, ч, ш, щ, г, к, х
Declension endings follow specific spelling rules. One of the most important to remember is:
Аfter ж, ч, ш, щ, г, к, х always write -и, never ы.
русский танк (Russian tank, masculine inanimate)
русская книга (Russian book, feminine inanimate)
русское поле (Russian field, neuter)
русские танки / книги / поля (Russian tanks/ books/ fields)
большой завод (large factory, masculine inanimate)
большая проблема (large problem, feminine inanimate)
большое озеро (large lake, neuter)
большие заводы / проблемы / озлра (large factories/ problems/ lakes)

td.p: Plural - one form for Masculine, Feminine and Neuter

div.p: Short Possessive Adjectives Declension
This type of possessive adjectives is formed by adding the suffix -ин, or -ов to a noun stem:
отцов костюм (father's suit, masculine inanimate)
мамин костюм (mother's suit, masculine inanimate)
отцова книга (father's book, feminine inanimate)
мамина дочка (mother's daughter, feminine animate)
отцово поле (father's field, neuter)
мамино поле (mother's field, neuter)
отцовы костюмы / книги / поля (father's suits/ books/ fields)
мамины костюмы / книги / поля (mother's suits/ books/ fields)

td.p: Plural - one form for Masculine, Feminine, Neuter

div.p: The Declension of Adjectives ending in: -ий, -ья, -ье , or -ьи
волчий хвост (wolf's tail, masculine inanimate)
волчья нора (wolf's den, feminine inanimate)
птичье гнездо (bird's nest, neuter)
The Superlative Degree of Adjectives
The superlative degree of adjectives is declined
in a mixed pattern:
красивейший костюм (the most beautiful suit, masculine inanimate)
красивейшая книга (the most beautiful book, feminine inanimate)
красивейшее поле (the most beautiful field, neuter)
ближайший дом (the nearest house, masculine inanimate)
ближайшая родственница (the closest relative, feminine animate)
ближайшее село (the nearest village, neuter)

td.p: Plural - one form for Masc., Fem., Neut.

div.p:
See Also:
Adjectives
Types of Adjectives
Long and Short Adjectives
Comparative and Superlative Adjectives
Sequence of Adjectives in a Noun Phrase
Noun-Adjective Agreement

item.title: Sequence of Adjectives in a Noun Phrase

div.p: Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

p.span: Sequence of Adjectives in a Noun Phrase

div.p: If more than one adjective precedes a noun in a noun phrase, the adjectives follow a set order, shown below. This order is determined by the degree of generality of each type of adjective.
First position: все (all), оба (both), несколько (a few, some), and cardinal numerals.
Second position: possessive adjectives (мой, твой)
Third position: ordinal numerals
(последний (last), второй (second), первый (first)).
Fourth position: adjectives of general description.
Fifth position: adjectives of size, shape, and color (relative adjectives).
все молодые девушки (1st, 4th positions)
(all young girls)
обе молодые девушки (1st, 4th positions)
(both young girls)
оба моих старших брата (1st, 2nd, 4th positions)
(both my older brothers)
3/4 нашего домашнего задания (1st, 2nd, 4th positions)
(3/4 of our homework)
последние десятичные цифры (3rd, 4th positions)
(the last decimal digits)
пять ел французских друзей (1st, 2nd, 4th positions)
(five of her French friends)
наши прекрасные большие члрные стулья (2nd, 4th ,5th, 5th positions)
(our beautiful large black chairs)
Depending on the meaning you would like to express 4th and 5th positions may be swapped:
наши большие прекрасные члрные стулья (2nd, 5th, 4th ,5th, positions)
(our large beautiful black chairs)
Note that a comma is used to separate adjectives in a noun phrase:
наши большие, прекрасные, члрные стулья

See Also:
Adjectives
Types of Adjectives
Adjective Declension
Comparative and Superlative Forms
Noun-Adjective Agreement
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Adjectives agree in number, gender, case and animacy with the noun they modify. For example, if the noun is masculine singular, the adjective has a masculine singular ending. If the noun is feminine singular, the adjective has a corresponding feminine singular ending. Agreement with animacy of a noun only affects the accusative case:
высокий дом (tall house)
-ий is the ending of the masculine singular nominative case and дом is the masculine singular noun.
высокая стена (high wall)
-ая is the ending of the feminine singular nominative case and стена is the feminine singular noun.
Я живу в большом доме. (I live in a big house.)
-ом is the ending of the masculine singular prepositional case and доме is the masculine singular prepositional case of дом.

The one exception to the rule of Noun Adjective agreement occurs when the noun is also modified by a numeral 2 or above. When one of these numerals is modifying the noun, the adjective is governed by the case requirements of the numeral. See Numerals.
Plural adjectives agree in number, case, and animacy with the nouns they modify. They do not change to reflect gender:
В зоопарке мы видели красивых зверей и интересные деревья.
(We saw beautiful animals and interesting trees at the zoo.)
Красивых зверей and интересные деревья are in the accusative case and are all plural.

Звери (animals) is an animate noun and деревья (trees) is an inanimate noun. Thus, красивых and интересные are in different forms of the accusative case, reflecting the animacy or the inanimacy of the nouns they modify.

Short form adjectives in the predicate of the sentence agree with the noun they modify as well. Short form adjectives do not change their case. They have only 4 endings: masculine singular, feminine singular, neuter singular, and plural:
Все звери были красивы. (All of the animals were beautiful.)
Звери and красивы are both plural.
Зверь был красив. (The animal was beautiful.)
Зверь and красив are both in the masculine singular.
When there are multiple nouns preceded by one adjective, the meaning is affected by the number of the adjective. For example,
большая тетрадь и книга (a large notebook and a book)
большие тетрадь и книга (a large notebook and a large book)

See Also:
Adjectives
Types of Adjectives
Adjective Declension
Long and Short Adjectives
Comparative and Superlative Forms
Sequence of Adjectives in a Noun Phrase
Gender of Nouns
Forms of the Predicate
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Some adjectives require an indirect object (dative case) when they are used predicatively, because the verbs from which they are derived also require an indirect object.:
Он был благодарен детям. (He was grateful to the children.)
Благодарен is the short form, masculine singular of the adjective благодарный.
Это было хорошо знакомо детям. (This was well known to the children.)
Знакомо is the short form, neuter singular of the adjective знакомый.

See Also:
Adjectives
Types of Adjectives
Adjective Declension
Long and Short Adjectives
Comparative and Superlative Forms
Sequence of Adjectives in a Noun Phrase
Gender of Nouns
Forms of the Predicate
Dative
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Adverbs modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs in the sentence:
Они двигались быстро. (They moved swiftly.)
Они шли вперлд. (They went forward.)
Она почти сдала экзамены. (She almost passed the exams.)
Новый офис расположен более удобно. (The new office is located more conveniently.)
Adverbs can also influence the meaning of the whole sentence and express the different relations between clauses and independent sentences:
Мальчик болен. Поэтому он не пришлл в школу.
(The boy is sick. Therefore, he didn't come to school.)
Дождь не идлт. Наоборот, солнце сияет.
(It isn't raining. On the contrary, the sun is shining.)
Я люблю русскую литературу, особенно Толстого.
(I love Russian literature, especially Tolstoy.)

See Also:
Types of Adverbs Classified by Meaning
Comparative and Superlative Adverbs
Predicative Adverbs
Adverb Formation
Adverbial Phrases
Adverbial Clauses
History of the Russian Language
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Adverbs of Manner
Он двигался быстро и бесшумно. (He moved swiftly and silently.)
Девочка читает очень медленно. (The girl is reading very slowly.)
Adverbs of Time
Он проснулся рано утром. (He woke up early in the morning.)
Она всегда жалуется. (She always complains.)
Adverbs of Distance and Direction
Он шлл прямо вперлд.
(He went straight ahead.)
Adverbs of Degree
(Adverbs used to emphasize and intensify)
Все ел очень любят. (Everyone loves her very much.)
Он совершенно не понял замечаний жены.
(He completely misunderstood his wife's remarks.)
Мы были полностью изнурены дорогой.
(We were utterly exhausted by the trip.)
Она довольно сердита на меня. (She is pretty mad at me.)
Interrogative Adverbs
Когда он приедет? (When will he arrive?)
Где это произошло? (Where did it happen?)
See Adverb Formation. Negative Adverbs
Negative adverbs are formed from interrogative adverbs by adding the prefixes не- and ни-:

td.p: никак (by no means, in no way)

div.p: Я так занята школой и работой, что мне некогда ходить в кино с друзьями.
(I am so busy with work and school, that there is no time for me to go to the movies with my friends.)
Он никогда не бывал в Париже. (He had never been to Paris.)
Note that negative adverbs are frequently accompanied by negative particles.
Indefinite Adverbs
Particles -то, -либо, -нибудь, and кое- are used to form indefinite adverbs:
почему-то (for some reason)
почему-либо (for some reason or other),
зачем-то (for some reason)
когда-нибудь (some day, at some time (future))
когда-то (some day, at some time (past))
где-либо (somewhere anywhere)
где-то (somewhere)
как -то (somehow)
как-нибудь (somehow)
куда-то (to somewhere)
кое где( in places, here and there)
откуда-то (from somewhere)
кое-как (somehow/anyhow)
куда-нибудь (to somewhere, to anywhere)
откуда-то (from anywhere).
Он когда-нибудь приедет. (Someday, he will come.)
Это произошло когда-то давно. (It happened sometime ago.)
Кое-где лежал снег. (There was snow here and there.)
Он почему-то не пришлл. (For some reason he didn't come.)
Если Вы где-либо потеряетесь, позвоните мне, пожалуйста.
(If you get lost somewhere, please call me.)

See Also:
Adverbs
Comparative and Superlative Adverbs

item.title: Comparative and Superlative Degrees of Adverbs

div.p: Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

p.span: Comparative and Superlative Degrees of Adverbs

div.p: As with adjectives, there are two regular methods to form comparative adverbs: with the suffixes -ее, -ей or with the words более (more) and менее (less):
весело (merry) - веселее (merrier)
красиво (beautiful) - более красиво (more beautiful)
To form the superlative form of adverbs, add -ейше/-айше or a comparative adverb + всего (of all):
глубоко (deeply - глубочайше (most deeply)
глубоко (deeply) - глубже всего (deepest of all)
строго (strictly) - строжайше (strictly)
The prefix -наи is used to express extreme degree with superlative forms:
строго (strictly) - наистрожайше (most strictly)
Irregular Forms of Comparison
хорошо (good), плохо (bad), много (much, many), мало (little).

See Also:
Adverbs
Types of Adverbs
Adverbial Phrases
Adverbial Clauses
Adverb Formation
Comparative and Superlative Adjectives
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Predicative adverbs stand quite apart in Russian grammar. Syntactically these adverbs are a part of the predicate of the impersonal sentence. The logical subject (if there is one) is in the dative case:
Мне было холодно. (I was cold. (Literally: It was cold to me.)
Мне приятно это слышать. (It is a pleasure for me to hear that.)
Вам будет трудно начать. (It will be difficult for you to start.)
Как это интересно! (How interesting this is!)
Нам стало трудно дышать. (It became hard for us to breathe.)
Мне (to, for me), вам (to, for you), нам (to, for us) are logical subjects in the dative case of the personal pronouns я (I), вы (you), мы (we).
Было (was) and будет (will be) are forms of the auxiliary verb быть (to be) in the past and future respectively.
They form impersonal predicates было холодно (it was cold), будет трудно (it will be difficult).
Note that in the present there is no auxiliary verb since the present tense form of быть is usually omitted.
Стало (it became) is a past singular neuter form of another auxiliary verb стать (to become). This verb is also frequently used in the impersonal predicate.
На улице стало темно.
Some predicative adverbs coincide in form with short neuter adjectives. They may have a comparative degree:
Сегодня жарче, чем вчера.
(It is hotter today than yesterday.)
Жарче (hotter) is a comparative form of the adverb жарко (hot), which is formed from the adjective жаркий (hot).
Здесь в тени приятнее стоять.
(It is more pleasant to stand here in the shade.)
Приятнее (more pleasant) is a comparative form of the adverb приятно (pleasant),which is formed from the adjective приятный (pleasant).
Necessity, possibility, or impossibility are also expressed by predicative adverbs
in Russian grammar (in English, modal verbs are used for the same purpose):
Вам нельзя много работать. (You shouldn't work too much.)
Мне пора на работу. (It is time for me to go to work.)

See Also:
Adverbs
Types of Adverbs
Adverbial Phrases
Adverbial Clauses
Adverb Formation
Impersonal Verbs and Constructions
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Pronouns allow speakers to refer to an expression without having to repeat it. For example:
Этот новый дом был сильно разрушен ураганом. This new house was badly damaged when it was hit by the hurricane.
In the sentence above, the pronoun "it" refers back to the noun phrase "this new house".
Russian pronouns are divided into the following categories:

See Also:
Nouns
Subject-Predicate Agreement
History of the Russian Language
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Presented below are the pronouns in the nominative case representing the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd persons, singular and plural.
Personal pronouns can be used in various ways within a sentence:
They can serve as the subject of the sentence :
Она любит танцевать. (She loves to dance.)
They can serve as the indirect object of the sentence:
Павел рассказал ей интересную историю. (Paul told her an interesting story.)
The declension of singular personal pronouns in their six cases:
The declension of plural personal pronouns:
See Usage of Personal Pronouns.

See Also:
Pronouns
Reflexive Pronouns
Possessive Pronouns
Definite Pronouns
Indefinite Pronouns
Negative Pronouns
Interrogative and Relative Pronouns
Demonstrative Pronouns
Subject-Predicate Agreement
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
The first person singular pronoun я (I) is frequently omitted in Russian, its meaning inferred from the verb ending in the sentence:
Хожу по лесу, собираю грибы.
(I am walking through the woods, I am gathering mushrooms.)
Although this sentence does not contain the personal pronoun я (I), the у/ю ending of the verbs хожу and собираю clearly identify the subject of the sentence as being in the first person singular.
Note: The pronoun я, the equivalent of 'I', is not capitalized as it is in English, unless it comes at the beginning of a sentence or a title.
Usage of formal and informal address, Вы and ты, in the Singular

The polite вы is always used when addressing one's elders, superiors at work or school, and people one has just met. The familiar ты is used to address children, family members, and close friends. Never switch from the formal to the familiar without first announcing your desire to do so and obtaining the other person's consent. The standard phrase used to switch from вы to ты in Russian is:
Давайте будем на ты! ( Let's be informal.)
Note : The singular polite form of you, вы, is usually capitalized only in formal or business correspondence.
Determining Gender of 1st and 2nd Person Singular Pronouns

The first and second person singular pronouns я and ты/вы are not gender-specific and can refer to any gender. The gender can be deduced, though, from the endings of the past tense verbs associated with these pronouns:
Я гуляла в саду. ( I strolled through the garden.)
Я гулял в саду. ( I strolled through the garden.)

Although the pronoun used in both sentences is identical, we can identify the first speaker's gender as feminine by the -а ending (characteristic of past tense verbs in the feminine gender) in гуляла.
Gender can also be deduced from the adjectives associated with the pronoun in the sentence:
Ты очень умная и красивая. (You are very beautiful and intelligent.)
Ты очень умный и красивый. (You are very beautiful and intelligent.)

The pronoun ты is used in both constructions, yet the first sentence is clearly addressed to a female, as we can see by the feminine -ая adjectival ending, while the second sentence uses the masculine adjectival ending -ый, and, therefore, refers to a male.
Usage of 3rd Person Pronouns

The third person singular pronouns, он, она, оно clearly show the gender of the noun they are referring to: he, she, it. Because animals and inanimate objects, as well as people, reflect gender in Russian nouns, он and она are frequently translated as "it" in English:
Шлл такой сильный дождь, что казалось он потопит весь мир.
(Such a hard rain was falling, that it seemed it would drown the whole world)
In this example we see the pronoun он (he) used to refer to the masculine inanimate noun дождь (rain).
Lack of Gender in the Plural Pronouns
The plural pronouns мы, вы, and они do not show gender. This pronouns can refer to all feminine, all masculine, all neuter, or to both masculine, feminine, and neuter nouns together:
Белые берлзы- они напоминают мне о России.
(White birches- they remind me of Russia.)
Чеченцы- гордый народ, они всегда сопротивлялись России.
(The Chechens are a proud people, they have always resisted Russia.)

In these two examples, we see the plural third person pronoun они (they) used to refer to both the inanimate plural берлзы (birches), which is a feminine noun when in its singular form, and to the animate plural чеченцы (Chechens).
Spelling Change for 3rd Person Pronouns with Prepositions
An important rule to remember when spelling personal pronouns in the third person singular and plural is the addition of the letter н when these pronouns are preceded by a preposition:
Наташа с ней училась в школе. (Natasha went to school with her.)
Газеты пишут о нлм всякую ерунду. (The newspapers write all sorts of nonsense about him.)
У них дома всегда весело. (It's always merry at their house.)

See Also:
Personal Pronouns
Pronouns

Negative Pronouns

The reflexive pronoun себя always refers back to the nearest subject. It expresses the idea of 'myself, yourself, himself/herself/itself, themselves.' Since it can't be a subject itself, there is no nominative form. The reflexive pronoun declines, but does not change for gender or number. The declension is as follows:
The reflexive pronoun is always used to refer to the subject of the sentence. The subject and the object, therefore, are the same person:
Они винили себя. (They blamed themselves.)
Она готовила себе обед. (She was preparing dinner for herself.)
Он говорил о себе. (He spoke about himself.)

The possessive pronoun себя fulfills a function similar to that of the reflexive verb suffix -ся , which also signifies that the recipient of the action, the object, is the same as the subject in a sentence:
Он мылся. (He washed himself.) Reflexive verb usage.
Он себя мыл. (He washed himself.) Reflexive pronoun usage.

See Also:
Pronouns
Personal Pronouns
Possessive Pronouns
Definite Pronouns
Indefinite Pronouns
Negative Pronouns
Interrogative and Relative Pronouns
Subject-Predicate Agreement
Imperative Mood
Infinitives
Participles
Reflexive Verbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Possessive pronouns are used to show possession of something. They answer the question: чей? (whose?)
Чей ты сын? (Whose son are you?)
Я твой сын. (I am your son.)
The nominative forms of the possessive pronouns are:

In Russian, there are distinctive possessive pronouns for the first and second person singular and plural- мой, твой, наш, ваш (my, your, our and your). The possessive pronoun свой (one's own) can be used by all of the above. These pronouns always agree with the noun they modify in gender, number and case.
For example, look at how the possessive pronoun мой changes to correspond to the noun it modifies in the following sentences:
Мои собаки очень послушные. (My dogs are very obedient.)- Plural,nominative.
Я люблю мою маму. ( I love my mother.)- Singular, feminine, accusative
Мы недалеко от моего дома. (We are not far from my house.)- Singular, masculine, genitive.
As with adjectives, the plural possessive pronouns for our and your (plural) are the same for all three genders, they only show number (plural) and case.
The possessive pronouns свой (one's own), твой (your), мой (my) have a similar declension pattern. Presented below is the declension of мой (my):
The possessive pronouns наш (our), and ваш (your, plural) have a similar declension pattern as well. Presented below is the declension of наш (our):
The possessive pronouns for the third person singular and plural are the same as the genitive forms of the personal pronouns он, она, оно, они:
Мы его искали, но не нашли. (We searched for him, but didn't find him.)
Мы нашли его дом. (We found his house.)

In the first example, его is the personal pronoun он in the genitive case. In the second example, его refers to the noun дом (house), and shows possession. The third person possessive pronouns differ from the first and second person possessive pronouns in that they do not change to reflect the case, gender and number of the noun they modify. Consider the following examples:
Я читала ел книги. (I read her books.)- Plural, accusative
Он подъехал к ел дому. (He drove up to her house.)- Singular, masculine, dative.
Они игрались с ел собаками. (They played with her dogs.)- Plural, instrumental.

As these three sentences demonstrate, the possessive third person pronoun maintains the genitive case of the personal form, and does not reflect the noun it modifies, but, rather, reflects the grammatical gender of the noun it replaces.

See Also:
Pronouns
Personal Pronouns
Reflexive Pronouns
Definite Pronouns
Indefinite Pronouns
Negative Pronouns
Interrogative and Relative Pronouns
Subject-Predicate Agreement
Genitive
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Demonstrative pronouns can be used to modify a noun or they can stand alone. In Russian, the most frequently used demonstrative pronouns are :
этот (this)
тот (that)
такой (such )
While такой declines like a hard adjective, этот and тот decline as follows:
For the declension of такой see Adjective Declension.
In Russian, demonstrative pronouns agree with the noun they modify in gender, number and case when they are used as adjectives:
Я обожаю эти розы. ( I adore these roses.)- plural, inanimate, accusative.
Он предпочитал ехать той дорогой. ( He preferred to travel by that road.)-
singular, feminine, instrumental.
However, when этот (this) is used as the subject, it is always used in the neuter, nominative, singular form это, and gives the meaning 'This is':
Это моя жена. (This is my wife.)
Это наш дом. (This is our house.)

See Also:
Pronouns
Personal Pronouns
Reflexive Pronouns
Definite Pronouns
Indefinite Pronouns
Negative Pronouns
Interrogative and Relative Pronouns
Possessive Pronouns
Subject-Predicate Agreement
Types of Adjectives
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
The interrogative/relative pronouns include:
кто (who)
что (what)
чей (whose)
какой (what kind)
который (which)
These pronouns can either ask a question (interrogative) or introduce a clause in a sentence (relative):
Кто это сделал? (Who did this?) - interrogative
Тот, кто сейчас смелтся. (The one who is laughing right now.) - relative
Который писатель самый великий? (Which writer is the greatest one?) - interrogative
Тот, который написал 'Отелло'. (The one which (who) wrote "Othello".) - relative

The interrogative/relative pronouns какой (what kind) and который (which) change to reflect the gender and number of the noun they modify, and decline in the same pattern as hard adjectives (those ending in -ой and ый). See Adjective Declension.

The pronoun чей (whose) also changes to reflect the gender and number of the noun it modifies, and declines in the same pattern as possessive adjectives which end in -чий, such as волчий (wolf-like, or belonging to a wolf) and собачий (dog-like, or belonging to a dog). See Adjective Declension.
The pronouns кто (who), and что (what) do not reflect the number or gender of the noun they modify. In most cases when кто is used, the predicate is in the masculine singular:
Кто постучал к нам в дверь? Мама постучала. / Братья постучали.
(Who knocked on our door? Mom knocked on the door / Our brothers knocked
on the door.)

In this sentence кто is modified by the verb постучал which is in the masculine singular form, although the answer to the question may identify мама (mom), which is feminine, or братья (brothers), which is masculine plural, as the agent of the action.
Note: A singular or plural predicate may be used with кто when this relative pronoun is preceded by the word все(all) in a sentence:
Все, кто хотел/хотели поехал/поехали на экскурсию.
(All who wished, went on the excursion.)
The declension pattern of кто/что:

Pronouns

Such pronouns refer to indefinite (sometimes unknown) persons or things, or to indefinite quantities. Some common indefinite pronouns are:
кто-то (someone)
что-то (something)
кое-кто (some, a few)
кое-что (something, a little)
кто-нибудь (anyone)
что-нибудь (anything)
какой-то (some kind of)
какой-нибудь (any kind)
некто ( someone, a certain person)
нечто (a certain something)

The indefinite pronouns некто and нечто are not declined. The rest of the indefinite pronouns follow the same patterns of declension as their interrogative/relative counterparts. The particles кое-, -нибудь, and -то, which transform the interrogative/relative into the indefinite pronouns, are not declined.
Некто таинственный оставил вам цветы. (A certain mysterious someone
has left flowers for you.)
Какой-то мальчишка разбил наше окно. (Some boy broke our window.)
Кто-то хлопнул дверью. (Someone slammed the door.)
Она чем-то взволнована. (She is upset by something.)
Если кто-нибудь проголодается, покушайте пирог. (If anyone gets hungry, eat the cake.)
Вам что-нибудь нужно? (Do you need anything?)

This group of pronouns can also be used alone or to modify other words. Some definitive pronouns include:
сам (self)
самый (the very, the most, the same)
весь (all/the whole)
всякий (all kinds of)
каждый (each, every)
любой (any)
На прошлой неделе каждый день шлл дождь. (It rained every day last week.)
Одесса - самый прелестный город. (Odessa is the most lovely city.)
Любой культурный человек читал Шекспира. (Any educated person has read
Shakespeare.)
Весь сад расцвлл в апреле. (The entire garden bloomed in April.)
Она болтала всякие глупости. (She chattered all sorts of foolish nonsense.)
Он сам справился с задачей.(He solved the problem by himself.)
Сам (self) can be used to describe something done on one's own, without any help:
Он сам построил дом. (He built the house himself.)
Сам can also describe something done personally, or in person:
Я с ней сам поговорю. (I will speak to her personally.)
Сам declines as follows:
Самый can be used to express three separate meanings:
It can convey the meaning of 'the very' when modifying nouns:
Дорога привела нас в самую глубь леса. (The road led us to the very depth of the woods.)
It can convey the meaning of 'the most' when modifying adjectives:
Гоголь- самый талантливый писатель. (Gogol is the most talented writer.)
It can convey the emphatic meaning of 'the same' when used with тот or тот же (that), and with этот (this):
Это тот самый учитель, который преподовал в моей школе. (This is the same teacher who taught at my school.)
Весь (all/the whole) also means 'everything' when it is in its neuter singular form всл, аnd 'everyone' when it is in the nominative plural form все:
Мы всл узнали. (We found out everything.)
Все рассмеялись. (Everyone burst out laughing.)
Весь declines as follows:

Negative pronouns act as they do in English with one important exception. Negative pronouns in Russian require the use of the particle не (the equivalent of 'not') before the predicate in the sentence. A literal translation of a sentence including a negative pronoun would be, "No one cannot come in."
Some negative pronouns include:
никто (nobody)
ничто, ничего (nothing)
никакой (not any kind)
ничей (nobody's)
Никто не пришлл к нам в гости. (Nobody came to visit us.)
Он ничего не понимал. (He did not understand anything.)
Это никакая не музыка. (This isn't any kind of music.)
Мальчишка ничьи яблоки не воровал. (The boy did not steal anyone's apples.)
The negative pronouns decline in the same pattern as the corresponding interrogative/ relative pronouns.

An important rule to remember when using negative pronouns is the placement of prepositions in cases when these are needed in the sentence. When a preposition is present, it is always placed after the ни:
Она ни в члм не виновна. (She is not guilty of anything.)
Он ни о ком не думает. (He doesn't think about anyone else.)
Мы ни на какую прогулку не пошли. (We didn't go on any outing/ walk.)

Numerals can be divided into several categories in Russian. Cardinal numerals are used for counting and identify the number of an item. Cardinal numerals 2 and above affect the case of the noun and any modifying adjectives that are being counted. Ordinal numerals convey the ideas of 'first, second, third,' etc. Ordinal numerals act like adjectives and have adjectival endings. Collective numerals are used to count items that have no singular and can be used for counting small groups. The words that mean 'several, some, a few, not many,' etc. are referred to as indefinite numerals in Russian and affect the case of the modified noun and adjectives. Fractional numerals express the ideas of 'one half, two thirds,' etc. as they do in English.

See Also:
Cardinal Numerals
Ordinal Numerals
Fractional Numerals
Collective Numerals
Indefinite Numerals
Time
Dates
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Cardinal numerals are divided into groups, each of which has its own set of rules. A summary of the rules governing cardinal numerals and the nouns and adjectives they modify is presented below.
The masculine, feminine, neuter and plural forms of the cardinal numeral "one" in the nominative case are:
один, одна, одно, одни
The numeral 1 agrees with the noun it modifies in gender, number and case. When this numeral stands alone it agrees with its antecedent in gender and number:
Одной ночью мы увидели в лесу медведя.
(One night we saw a bear in the woods.)
The numeral 1 in this sentence is singular, feminine, and in the instrumental case, to agree with the noun ночью, which it modifies.
In Russian, a noun, modified by a compound numeral, agrees with the final element of that numeral. When the final element is один/одна/одно the modified noun is singular:
(forty one doves)
Long adjectives or participles are also in the singular, as is the verb in the sentence:
Тридцать один голубь взлетел в небо.
(Thirty one doves flew up into the sky.)
The noun голубь as well as the verb взлетел are in their singular form.
Agreement with Nouns in Numerals 2 and above

Starting with the numeral 2, it is important to recognize whether the numeral is in the nominative (or the identical inanimate accusative form) or in one of the other cases, referred to as oblique cases. Numerals in the nominative or inanimate accusative case determine the case of the adjectives and nouns they modify. Numerals in the oblique cases agree with the noun they modify.
два (masculine) / две (feminine), три, четыре

The numeral 2 has both a masculine and feminine form, as noted above. When 2, 3 or 4 is in the nominative or in the inanimate accusative form they require that the noun they modify be in the genitive singular:
три собаки. (three dogs.)
The noun "собаки" is the genitive singular of the feminine noun "собака."
четыре космонавта. (four astronauts.)
The noun "космонавта" is the genitive singular of the masculine noun "космонавт."
The adjective, however, is in the genitive plural for masculine and neuter nouns and in the nominative plural for those modifying feminine nouns:
три охотничьи собаки. (three hunting dogs.)
The adjective "охотничьи" is the nominative plural of the adjective "охотничий".
четыре храбрых космонавта. (four courageous astronauts.)
The adjective "храбрых" is the genitive plural of the adjective "храбрый".
As with all numerals in oblique cases, the case of the numeral is governed by the case of the noun it modifies:
Он искал трлх охотничьих собак.
(He searched for three hunting dogs.)
The numeral "трлх" is in the animate accusative case here, as is the noun it modifies, "собак".
Страна гордилась четырьмя храбрыми космонавтами.
(The country was proud of the four courageous astronauts.)
The numeral "четырьмя" is in the instrumental case, to agree with the noun it modifies, "космонавтами".
Compound numerals ending in 2, 3 and 4 (i.e., 62, 823, 794) follow the same rules as for the numerals 2, 3, 4.
пять - девятьсот девяносто девять
These numerals require the noun and the adjective to be in the genitive plural case (when the numeral is in the nominative form):
восемь коров (eight cows)
The noun "коров" is the genitive plural of the noun "корова."
сто двадцать пять рублей.
(one hundred and twenty five rubles)
The noun "рублей" is the genitive plural of the noun "рубль".
тысяча, миллион, миллиард
These numerals require the genitive plural of the noun and adjective regardless of their own case:
Миллион голубых звлзд сияют в члрном небе.
(A million of light blue stars are shining in the black sky.)
The numeral "миллион" is in the singular nominative case, while the noun (звезда) and the adjective (голубой) it modifies are in the plural genitive case.
Он любовался миллионом голубых звлзд.
(He gazed at the million light blue stars.)
The numeral "миллион" is in the instrumental case here, but the noun (звезда) and the adjective (голубой) remain in the genitive plural.

All ordinal numerals act as adjectives and agree with the noun they modify in gender, number and case. Thus, ordinal numerals will always have one of the characteristic adjectival endings: -ый, -ой, -ий for masculine; -ое for neuter; and -ая for the feminine gender when in the nominative case. Like adjectives, ordinal numerals decline to agree with the noun they modify.
Это мой первый урок. (This is my first lesson.)
The ordinal numeral первый (first) is masculine, singular, and in the nominative case here, in order to agree with the noun урок (lesson).
Сойдите с поезда на пятой остановке. (Get off the train at the fifth stop.)
The ordinal numeral пятая is feminine, singular, and in the prepositional case in this sentence, to show agreement with the noun it modifies, остановка (stop).
Ordinal numerals which end in -ой when in the masculine singular, will always have that syllable stressed:
второй (2nd)
шестой (6th)
седьмой (7th)
восьмой (8th)
All ordinal numerals decline like hard adjectives, with the exception of the numeral третий, which declines like the possessive adjectives of the type "собачий" (dog-like, or belonging to a dog).

The following is a table of the most commonly used fractional numerals. Please note that the numerator одна (one) can be omitted in fractions where the denominator is three and four:
Собака съела всего лишь треть своей еды.
(The dog ate only a third of its food.)
Он вернлтся через четверть часа.
(He will return in a quarter of an hour.)

td.p: one and a half (masculine and neuter)

div.p: Nouns which follow fractions (with the exception of one and a half and one hundred and fifty) are always put in the genitive case regardless of the case the fraction may be in:
Наташа уже прочитала три четверти книги.
(Natasha has already read three quarters of the book.)
Облако затмило половину неба.
(The cloud covered half of the sky.)
The numerator in fractions other than those shown in the table is always cardinal, while the denominator is ordinal, and in the genitive plural case.
Мы получили пять девятых нашей зарплаты.
(We received five ninths of our salary.)
The following table demonstrates the declension patterns of the fractions четверть (one fourth), треть (one third), половина (one half) and a sample fraction пять шестых (five sixths):

The following table demonstrates the declension patterns of the fractions полтора (one and a half- masc. and neuter), полторы (one and a half- feminine), and полтораста (one hundred and fifty), with sample nouns which may follow these fractions in a sentence:

The contraction of the fractional numeral половина (one half) to пол-, which is then added to a noun in the singular genitive case, is a common way of expressing "half" in Russian. Note that a hyphen must be placed between the numeral contraction and the noun if that noun begins with a vowel, a capital letter, or the letter л:
полчаса (half an hour)
полгода (half a year)
полночь (midnight)
полдень(noon)
пол-озера (half the lake)
пол-Америки (half of America)
пол-литра (half a liter)

Collective numerals are used to identify a number of individual people or objects which function as a unity, or as a group. Frequently, collective numerals are used with nouns which have no singular form. Note that the noun described by collective numerals other than оба/обе (both), must be in the genitive plural. The collective numeral оба/обе (both) is followed by the genitive singular when it is in the nominative case:
Пятеро острых ножниц. (Five pairs of sharp scissors.)
Трое серълзных учеников. (Three serious students.)
Обе молодые учительницы. (Both of the young teachers.)
Шестеро члрных щенят. (Six black puppies.)

The collective numerals двое (two) and трое (three) decline in the same pattern, while the rest of the collective numerals decline like четверо (four). The following table shows the declension patterns of collective numerals with sample nouns:

Some grammar books will describe these words of quantity as indefinite numerals, and other as adverbs of measure. These words are used with the genitive singular or plural of the noun, depending on the context.

To ask or state the date, one must use the nominative case of the ordinal numeral. If the date is a compound number, the first numerals will be cardinal, while the last one will be ordinal. Note that the ordinal numeral must be in the neuter gender to agree with the neuter noun число (date), which is at times omitted, because it is understood:
Какое будет завтра число? (What is tomorrow’s date?)
Завтра будет двадцать пятое. (Tomorrow will be the twenty fifth.)
The name of the month must always be put in the genitive singular:
Завтра двадцать пятое декабря.
(Tomorrow will be the twenty fifth of December.)

To state the year of the date the last numeral (ordinal) and the word "год" (year) must be in the genitive singular. Note that because the noun "год" (year) is masculine, the ordinal numeral will agree with it, and take the masculine gender:
Завтра будет двадцать пятое декабря тысяча девятьсот девяносто пятого года.
(Tomorrow will be the twenty fifth of December, 1995.)
When describing an event that occurs on a particular date, the ordinal numerals, the name of the month, and the word "year" will all be in the genitive case:
Мы увидимся двадцать пятого декабря тысяча девятьсот девяносто пятого года.
(We will see each other on the twenty fifth of December, 1995.)

When writing or speaking about less exact dates, for example, mentioning only the year or the month of the event, the preposition "в" and the prepositional case for the month's name and the word "year" can be used:
В феврале он уехал в Японию. (In February he left for Japan.)
Война кончилась в сорок пятом году. (The war ended in 1945.)
Note that the names of the months are not capitalized in Russian.

See Also:
Time

Adverbial Clauses of Time
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
To inquire about the time of day, one should ask:
Который сейчас час? (What time is it?)

If the answer to that question is a whole hour, cardinal numerals are used, and the time of day (morning, day, evening, night), if identified, is in the genitive singular case. Note that the numeral один (one) can be omitted when speaking of one o'clock.
Три часа ночи (3:00 in the morning)
Девять часов вечера (9:00 in the evening)
Час дня (1:00 in the afternoon)

If one needs to describe the time more precisely, minutes and hours can be expressed with a combination of cardinal or fractional (to designate minutes) and ordinal (to designate hours) numerals, or solely with cardinal numerals, depending on the time.
If the time is before the half-hour mark, use a combination of cardinal (or fractional) and ordinal numerals. Note that the ordinal numeral will always be in the genitive singular, masculine form:
Приходите к нам в четверть шестого.
(Come visit us at a quarter past five. Literally: at a quarter of the sixth hour.)
Фильм начинается в пять минут десятого.
(The film starts at five after nine. Literally: at five minutes of the tenth hour.)
If the time is at the half-hour mark, the contraction пол- (of the fractional numeral "половина" (half)), can be attached to the ordinal numeral representing the hour.
Мы обычно обедаем в полседьмого.
(We usually eat at half past six. Literally: at the half of the seventh hour.)
Он позвонит в полвторого.
(He will call at one thirty. Literally: at the half of the second hour.)

If the time is after the half-hour mark, only cardinal and fractional numerals are used. The numerals denoting minutes will be in the genitive singular, while the numeral denoting the hour will be in the nominative case. Note that the preposition в is omitted, as is the word "minutes:"
Поезд появился без десяти шесть. (The train appeared at ten (minutes) till six. Literally: at six without ten (minutes).)
Цунами обрушилось на город без четверти три. (The tidal wave came down on the city at a quarter of three. Literally: at three without a quarter.)
If the number of minutes until the hour is below five, then the word минут (the genitive plural of минута (minute)) must be used:
Сейчас без двух минут шесть.
(It is two minutes till six. (Literally: six without two minutes.))
A common and simple way of expressing time is with cardinal numerals in the nominative case. Note that the numeral ноль (zero) is used for the hour designation between midnight and 1am:
пять двадцать (5:20)
шесть пятнадцать (6:20)
ноль десять (12:10 AM)
Note that Russia uses a 24-hour clock.

Particles are words that add different shades of meaning to other words in a sentence or to the sentence as a whole.
Negative Particles
не, ни
These particles negate the meaning of the word that follows with the general meaning 'not'.
Я вас не узнал. (I didn't recognize you.)
Interrogative Particles
ли, разве, неужели
These particles add an interrogative meaning to the sentence often with no real translation of their own.
Неужели вы не любите Моцарта?
(Is it really true that you don't like Mozart?)
Emphatic Particles
же, ж (No translation, placed after word it emphasizes. Can also give emotional nuance to the entire sentence.)
Я же вас предупредил, что это злая собака.
(But I warned you that this is a vicious dog!)
даже (even)
Она купалась в море каждый день, даже зимой.
(She swam in the sea every day, even in wintertime.)
ведь (after all)
Ему никто не верит- ведь он всегда лжлт.
(No one believes him - after all, he always lies.)

Prepositions are connecting words that show the relationships between other words in a sentence. Prepositions can denote purpose, space, cause, location, motion, or time.
Мы собираем грибы в лесу. (We are gathering mushrooms in the forest.)
Между кустами висела паутина. (A spiderweb hung between the bushes.)
Кораблик исчез за горизонтом. (The little ship disappeared beyond the horizon.)
Я встретилась с архитектором в среду. (I met with the architect on Wednesday.)
Prepositions + Noun Case

Most prepositions are associated with a specific case, though some can be used with several cases for different meanings. For information on prepositions that govern each case with examples, see the following topics:
There are both simple and compound prepositions in Russian. Compound prepositons are those composed of more than one word. See Compound Prepositions.

The nominative case is the only case that is not used with prepositions. There are however a few idiomatic exceptions to this rule. See Special Constructions.
See Also:
Preposition Spelling
Verb Idioms
Adverbial Phrases
History of the Russian Language
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Compound prepositions consist of more than one word. Some of these compound prepositions are formed from nouns and prepositions, while others are formed from gerunds and particles. Some of the most frequently used compound prepositions are shown in the table below:

td.p: preposition в+ the noun вид (appearance, form) in the prepositional case
preposition в+ the noun продолжение (continuation) in the accusative case.
preposition в+ the noun течение (flow, current) in the accusative case.
negative particle не+ the gerund of the verb считать (to count).
negative prefix не- + the gerund of the verb смотреть (to look) + the preposition на
preposition по+ the noun повод (reason, cause)in the dative case.
preposition по+ the noun случай (occasion, incident) in the dative case.

div.p: Несмотря на дождь, они гуляли по городу.
(Despite the rain, they strolled through the city.)
Трое в лодке, не считая собаки.
(Three in a boat, not counting a dog.)
По какому поводу вы мне позвонили вчера?
(Regarding what did you call me yesterday?)
В течение года мы научились говорить по-английски.
(In the course of the year, we learned to speak English.)

The following prepositions govern the nominative case in rather special constructions:
Что это за кино? (What kind of a movie this is?)
Что за ветер! (What a wind!)
По is followed by the nominative case of the numerals два, три, четыре, etc., in distributive constructions:
Дети получили по два подарка.
(The children received two presents each.)
В каждом доме по две квартиры.
(There are two apartments in each house.)

The preposition о has the form об if the following word starts with a vowel sound:
