Conjunctions join words, phrases, clauses, and sentences:
Я пришла, а он ушлл. (I came, but he left.)
Принеси мне бумагу и конверт. (Bring me paper and an envelope.)
Она его любила, потому-что он был очень добрым. (She loved him because he was very kind.)

There are two major groups of conjunctions, the coordinate and the subordinate. Coordinate conjunctions join equally important words or clauses, while the subordinate conjunctions are used to join a main clause to the subordinate clauses. Please refer to the sections below for a full explanation of these topics.

See Also:
Prepositions
Particles
Interjections
Compound and Complex Sentences
History of the Russian Language
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

The function of coordinate conjunctions in a sentence is to show the relationship between grammatically equal words or clauses. Coordinate conjunctions can be used to contrast or oppose, to show a connection, or to show a choice:
Он поскользнулся и упал. (He slipped and fell.)
Он двигался быстро, но бесшумно. (He moved quickly but quietly.)
Мы можем перейти через реку или сквозь лес. (We can go over the river or through the woods.)
Note that in Russian но (but) is always separated by a comma from the preceding coordinate element.
Some of the most commonly used coordinate conjunctions:

td.p: Попълм чай, а потом пойдлм спать.
(We'll drink some tea, and then we'll go to sleep.)
Вчера мы работали, а сегодня мы отдыхаем.
(Yesterday we worked, but today we rest.)
Погода ужасная- дожди да бури каждый день.
(The weather is terrible- rain and storms every day.)
Она хотела поехать в Рим, но денег не хватало.
(She wanted to go to Rome, but there wasn't enough money.)
(He rose, and she did as well.)
but on the other hand; but then; however
Они бедные, зато милые и порядочные.
(They are poor, but then they are charming and decent.)
В одном городе, а именно в Одессе, я встретил необыкновенного человека.
(In a certain city, in Odessa, to be exact, I met the most unusual person.)
Она позвонила ровно неделю назад, т.е. в понедельник утром.
(She called exactly a week ago, i.e., on Monday morning.)

div.p: To construct the expression either ... or use the conjunction или twice in the sentence:
Вечером мы пойдлм или в театр, или в кино. (In the evening, we will go either to the theater, or to the movies.)
To construct the expression neither ... nor, use the negative particle ни twice in the sentence:
Она не знала ни Гоголя, ни Достоевского. (She was familiar neither with Gogol, nor with Dostoyevsky.)

See Also:
Conjunctions
Punctuation with Coordinate Conjunctions
Subordinate Conjunctions
Compound and Complex Sentences
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
If only two elements (two words, two phrases, two clauses) are joined by a coordinate conjunction, no comma is needed before the conjunction:
Врач сказал ему не курить и не пить. (The doctor told him not to smoke and not to drink.)
Он сказал, что очень устал и идлт домой.
(He said that he was very tired and he was going home.)
If three or more units are joined, commas separate all but the last unit:
Приглашаются мужчины, женщины и дети. (Men, women, and children are welcome.)

See Also:
Conjunctions
Coordinate Conjunctions
Subordinate Conjunctions
Punctuation
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Unlike coordinate conjunctions, subordinate conjunctions join elements of unequal rank. Subordinate conjunctions may be used for comparison, to show reason or purpose and to express time relationships between clauses.
Свадьба была такая чудесная, как будто в сказке! (The wedding was so wonderful, as if in a fairy tale!)
Я не услышала что он сказал. (I didn't hear what he said.)
Она не прочитала книгу, так что не могла ел обсуждать. (She didn't read the book, thus she was unable to discuss it.)
Простите его, раз он извинился. (Forgive him, since he apologized.)
Some of the most frequently used subordinate conjunctions:

td.p: Она узнала, что он скоро приедет.
(She found out that he will arrive soon.)
Мама позвонила, чтобы узнать о поезде.
(Mom called in order to find out about the train.)
Раз это твоя собака, то ты за ней и убирай!
(Since this is your dog, you clean up after it!)
Он выглядел, как будто только что проснулся.
(He looked as if he just woke up.)
Маша опоздала, так что мы решили без нел.
(Masha was late, so we decided without her.)
Eсли солнце выйдет, мы пойдлм в парк.
(If the sun comes out, we'll go to the park.)
Она плавала в море даже зимой, хотя было очень холодно.
(She swam in the sea even in winter, though it was very cold.)
Пошлл дождь, впрочем, это не имело значения.
(It began to rain, however, that didn't matter.)
Пусть зима идлт, мы любим снег!
(He growled, just like a wild beast.)
Снежинки липли к окну словно кружевные занавеси.
(Snowflakes covered the window just like lace curtains.)
Чуть только я вошла, позвонил телефон.
(As soon as I came in, the phone rang.)
Eдва мы сошли с поезда, появилось такси.
(As soon as we got off the train, a taxi appeared.)
Ссора началась когда Плтр выключил телевизор.
(The argument started when Peter turned off the television set.)
Дома тихо, потому что дети в школе.
(he house is quiet, because the children are in school.)
(She is as beautiful as a goddess.)
Я подожду пока вы не вернлтесь.

div.p: See Subordinate Clauses for more details.

See Also:
Conjunctions
Coordinate Conjunctions
Punctuation with Coordinate Conjunctions
Subordinate Clauses
Compound and Complex Sentences
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

An interjection is a word or expression that is often given emotional value in the stream of speech. In print an interjection is usually followed by an exclamation mark. Interjections can express awe, disgust, gratitude and pain, and they can also incite others to action. Most linguists agree that interjections comprise the earliest parts of speech.
Some of the most frequently used interjections in Russian:

td.p: Увы, они никогда опять не встретились.

div.p:
See Also:
Prepositions
Particles
Conjunctions
Exclamatory Sentences (Exclamations)
Punctuation
History of the Russian Language
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Word formation describes the process of forming words with new meanings from other words. This process is usually accomplished by adding affixes. Prefixes are added at the beginning of words and usually apply the same meaning to different parts of speech. In contrast, suffixes, added at the end of words, tend to denote a specific part of speech.

The term 'productive' is used to describe affixes that are used universally within the language to produce the same effect on a word. For example, the suffix -л is used with all verbs to produce the masculine, past tense, and this is true even with new verbs that come into the vocabulary.
летать (to fly)- летал (flew)
Another method of word formation involves compound words. A compound word consists of a combination of two or more forms that behave grammatically as one word:
пар (steam) + возить (to transport, to drive to) = паровоз (steam-engine, locomotive)
мясо (meat) + рубка (chopping) = мясорубка (meat grinder).
For information on how suffixes, prefixes, and compounds are used to form parts of speech, see:
Verb formation, including imperfective and perfective prefixes and suffixes, and the prefixed verbs of motion and their corresponding prepositions are discussed in:

See Also:
History of the Russian Language
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
See the topics listed below for details:

See Also:
Word Formation
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
A prefix is added at the beginning of a word to create a new meaning. Prefixes are applied to nouns, adjectives, adverbs and verbs. For example:
писать (to write) -
переписать (to overwrite, to copy)
предписать (to prescribe)
подписать (to sign)
The following prefixes used in Russian are borrowed from Latin and Greek:
Latin prefixes
Greek prefixes

See Also:
Prefix Spelling
Verbs of Motion Prefixes
Word Formation
Suffixes
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Some suffixes used in Russian, like certain prefixes, can be traced to other languages as well. The following suffixes are used to create abstract nouns:
Latin, French and Greek noun suffixes:

td.p: action, state or condition; the result of an action or process
state of being; characteristic or quality; doctrine; distinctive usage, especially of language
condition or process; decease or abnormality

div.p:
See Also:
Word Formation
Prefixes
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Nouns are created by adding suffixes or by combining words to create compound nouns.
These nouns can then be further modified by the addition of suffixes that give particular meanings.

p.a: Formation of Masculine and Feminine Nouns

div.p: The different types of suffixes mentioned above are specific to nouns. Prefixes, on the other hand, can be applied to different parts of speech with the same general meaning. For a table of commonly used prefixes and their meanings, see:

See Also:
Nouns
Word Formation
Prefixes
Suffixes
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Productive suffixes help create nouns from verbs. Presented below are suffixes that denote the person performing the action:
The suffix -тель :
учить (to teach)- учитель (teacher)
вредить (to harm )- вредитель (one who does harm, spoiler)
содержать (to maintain)- содержатель (a proprietor, usually of an inn)
The suffix -арь:
пахать (to plow)- пахарь (ploughman)
лечить (to cure)- лекарь (doctor)
печь (to bake)- пекарь (baker)
(Note the alternation of the consonant (ч/к) in the root of the last two examples.)
The suffixes -чик, -льщик:
летать (to fly)- ллтчик (pilot)
переводить (to translate)- переводчик (translator)
носить (to carry)- носильщик (porter)
точить (to sharpen)- точильщик (knife-grinder)

See Also:
Nouns
Noun Formation
Word Formation
Prefixes
Suffixes
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Abstract nouns may indicate inner characteristics of animate beings :
-ость
гордый (proud)- гордость (pride)
рад (glad)- радость (gladness, joy)
зло (evil)- злость (malice, meanness)
Abstract nouns may indicate a process or the result of a process:
-ание, -ение
писать (to write)- писание (writing)
уметь (to know)- умение (know-how, competency)
решать (to decide, to solve)- решение (decision, solution)
Abstract nouns may also indicate a state :
-ота, -ство
брат (brother)- братство (brotherhood)
добрый (kind )- доброта (kindness)
красивый (beautiful)- красота (beauty)

See Also:
Nouns
Adjectives
Noun Formation
Word Formation
Prefixes
Suffixes
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
New words can also be created by forming compounds. Compound nouns are often formed with the insertion of the letters -o and -e between the two roots. For example,
пар (vapor) + ход (movement) = пароход (steamboat)
луч (ray)+ испускание (release) = лучеиспускание (radiation)
A noun compound can consist of the following composite forms:
noun + noun:
дом (house) + хозяйка (ruler, administrator) = домохозяйка (housekeeper)
мир (world) + воззрение (view, outlook) = мировоззрение (world-view)
adjective + noun:
чист (clean) + писание (writing) = чистописание (calligraphy)
старый (old)+ обряд (rite, ceremony) = старообрядчик (Old Believer),
красный (red) + нос (nose) = красноносый (red-nosed)

See Also:
Nouns

Word Formation
Prefixes
Suffixes

div.p: Suffixes are used to denote the masculine or feminine agent of an action. These suffixes are commonly used to denote profession. Presented below are suffixes that form masculine and feminine nouns:
* Used only after the letters д, т, з, с, ж instead of the -щик/-щица ending.

Nouns
Gender of Nouns
Noun Formation
Word Formation

Suffixes

Diminutive suffixes are used in Russian to denote smallness and to convey different shades of meaning, ranging from affection to disparagement.
книга (book)
книжка, книжечка, книжонка, книжоночка (small book)
мама (mom)
мамочка, мамуля, матушка (mommy)
дорога (road)
дорожка, дорожечка (small road)
Мария (Maria)
Маша, Машка, Машенька, Машуня, Машечка, Машута (various nicknames)
кот (cat)
котик, котенька (a small cat)

See Also:
Nouns
Augmentatives
Noun Formation
Word Formation
Prefixes
Suffixes
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
In Russian, augmentative suffixes usually denote largeness:
книга (a book)- книжища (a big book)
дом (a house)- домище, домина (an enormous house)
кот (a cat)- котище (a huge cat)

See Also:
Nouns
Diminutives

In Russian, augmentative suffixes usually denote largeness:
книга (a book)- книжища (a big book)
дом (a house)- домище, домина (an enormous house)
кот (a cat)- котище (a huge cat)

Adverb formation is more irregular than noun or adjective formation and has many idiomatic expressions from the Old Russian language. There are, however, fewer methods of forming adverbs than there are for nouns and adjectives.
Adverbs Formed from the Adjective Stem.
The most common method of adverb formation is the use of the suffix -о, which is added to the end of the adjective stem:
медленный (slow)- медленно(slowly)
уверенный (certain)- уверенно(certainly)
быстрый (quick)- быстро (quickly)
невнимательный (careless)- невнимательно (carelessly)
ранний (early)- рано (early)
Adverbs formed from adjectives ending in -ский, -цкий usually have the
-и ending, and frequently use the prefix по-:
английский (English)- по-английски (in English)
русский (Russian)- по-русски (in Russian)
дурацкий (foolish, ridiculous)- по-дурацки (foolishly)
мальчишеский (boyish)- мальчишески (boyishly)
иронический (ironic)- иронически (ironically)
A small group of adverbs are formed from soft type adjectives and end in -е:
крайний (extreme)- крайне(extremely)
внешний (external)- внешне(externally)
искренний (sincere)- искренне(sincerely)
Adverbs Formed from Participles
Participles are verbal forms that are used as adjectives. Adverbs can be formed from some participles just as they are formed from adjectives. For example:
verb: угрожать - to threaten
verb: раздражать - to irritate
Gerunds - Verbal Adverbs

Gerunds are verbal forms that always have adverbial meaning in Russian and are sometimes referred to as verbal adverbs (or adverbial participles). They usually replace adverbial clauses, but some gerunds can be used simply as adverbs. For example,
молча (silently)
For information on the formation of gerunds, see Gerund.
Adverbs Formed from Nouns.
Adverbs derived from nouns frequently have the same form as the noun in the instrumental case, and describe location, manner of action, time of day, or season:
See Adverbial Phrases.
Adverbs Formed from Pronouns.
Some adverbs are formed from possessive pronouns:
Adverbs Formed from Numerals.
Some adverbs are formed from ordinal numerals.
Other adverbs are formed from cardinal numerals and collective numerals:

To understand the usage of verbs in Russian it is necessary to understand the concept of aspect and the use of verbs of motion. The following topics explain the role of prefixes and suffixes in forming perfective/imperfective verbs and verbs of motion.

A sentence is a group of words expressing a complete thought. It begins with a capital letter and closes with a punctuation mark. Usually, a sentence consists of a subject and a predicate.

A clause may be defined in the same way as a sentence. Independent clauses can stand by themselves as a sentence. Subordinate clauses serve as part of a sentence but do not express a complete thought and cannot stand by themselves. They are subordinate to the main clause in a sentence.

See Also:
Sentences
Subordinate Clauses
Punctuation and Punctuation Style
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
A sentence is a group of words expressing a complete thought. It begins with a capital letter and closes with a punctuation mark.
Usually a sentence consists of a subject and a predicate.
Sentences are classified by types (declarative, interrogative, exclamatory, and imperative) and by number of subjects and predicates (simple sentences and compound or complex sentences).

See Also:
Subject and Predicate
Compound and Complex Sentences
Subordinate Clauses
Punctuation and Punctuation Style
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Declarative sentences make statements:
Ночью будет холодно. (It will be cold at night.)
Собака хочет поймать белку. (The dog wants to catch the squirrel.)
Жить в Москве очень дорого. (It is very expensive to live in Moscow.)

See Also:
Sentences
Interrogative Sentences (Questions)
Exclamatory Sentences (Exclamations)
Imperative Sentences(Commands)
Subject and Predicate
Compound and Complex Sentences
Subordinate Clauses
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Usually, only the predicate is expressed, while the subject is omitted in the imperative sentence:
Позвоните в среду. (Call on Wednesday!)
Оставь меня в покое! (Leave me alone!)

See Also:
Sentences
Declarative Sentences (Statements)
Interrogative Sentences (Questions)
Exclamatory Sentences (Exclamations)
Subject and Predicate
Compound and Complex Sentences
Subordinate Clauses
Imperative Mood
Infinitives
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Such sentences begin with an exclamatory phrase which consists of какой/ая/ое/ие (what) or как (how) and a part of the predicate.
Какие прелестные дети! (What lovely children!)
Какой вкусный обед! (What a delicious dinner.)
Как жарко здесь! (How hot it is here!)

See Also:
Sentences
Declarative Sentences (Statements)
Interrogative Sentences (Questions)
Imperative Sentences (Commands)
Subject and Predicate
Compound and Complex Sentences
Subordinate Clauses
Exclamation Points
Interjections
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Interrogative sentences are used to pose questions:
Ты меня любишь? (Do you love me?)
Пошла ли она на работу утром? (Did she go to work in the morning?)
See Interrogative-Word Questions.

See Also:
Sentences
Declarative Sentences (Statements)
Exclamatory Sentences (Exclamations)
Imperative Sentences (Exclamations)
Subject and Predicate
Compound and Complex Sentences
Subordinate Clauses
Question Marks
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
These questions begin with either an interrogative pronoun
Почему вы грустите? (Why are you sad?)
Как вы поживаете? (How are you?)
Где находится музей? (Where is the museum?)
Когда придлт поезд? (When will the train come?)
or an interrogative adverb.
Кто здесь живлт? (Who lives here?)
Что здесь происходит? (What is going on here?)

See Also:
Sentences
Declarative Sentences (Statements)
Exclamatory Sentences (Exclamations)
Imperative Sentences (Exclamations)
Subject and Predicate
Compound and Complex Sentences
Subordinate Clauses
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
The main grammatical parts of a sentence are a subject and a predicate. The subject is the topic of the sentence. The predicate is what is said about the subject.
Снег падал на ночной город.
(Snow fell on the nighttime city.)
Снег is the subject of the sentence.
The predicate is падал на ночной город.

See Also:
Forms of the Subject
Forms of the Predicate
Subject Predicate Agreement
Sentences
Subordinate Clauses
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
The most common forms of subject are nouns and pronouns:
Noun:
Маша любит играть на пианино.
(Masha likes to play piano.)
Pronoun:
Кто оставил книгу на полу?
Who left the book on the floor?
Noun phrases and noun clauses may be the subject of a sentence:
Noun phrase:
Девочка в бассейне- моя племянница.
(The girl in the pool is my niece).
Noun clauses:
Что вы видите и что вы получите- две разные вещи.
(What you see and what you get are two different things.)
Infinitive may function as a subject of a sentence:
Infinitive:
Пить- вредная привычка.
(Drinking is a bad habit.)

See Also:
Sentences
Forms of the Predicate
Subject Predicate Agreement
Subordinate Clauses
Nouns
Pronouns
Infinitives
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

The predicate of the sentence is what is said about the subject. The predicate does not always contains a verb in Russian in the present tense, since the present tense verb of being (быть) is omitted. In the past and future tenses, however, the most frequently encountered type of predicate will contain a verb:
Она слушала музыку. (She listened to music.)
Музыку (music) is the direct object of the past tense verb слушала (listened).
A linking verb together with an adjective can also be a part of the predicate:
Он кажется больным. (He seems sick.)
Больным (sick) is a complement of казаться (to seem). Without an adjective the linking verb does not form a meaningful sentence. Больным (sick) is the instrumental case of the adjective больной.

See Also:
Sentences
Forms of the Subject
Subordinate Clauses
Nouns
Pronouns
Infinitives
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
In order to form grammatically correct sentence certain parts of speech (verbs, nouns, pronouns) have to agree with each other in number (singular or plural) and person (first, second, or third):
Рим- самый чудесный город в мире.
(Rome is the most wonderful city in the world.)
In this sentence, город (city) is a part of the predicate, and agrees in number (singular in this case), with the subject of the sentence-- Рим (Rome).

See Also:
Sentences
Forms of the Subject
Forms of the Predicate
Subordinate Clauses
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Compound sentences have two or more independent clauses. Clauses are usually joined together by a comma followed by a conjunction (и, но, etc.). They may also be joined by a semicolon or a colon:
Мы не знаем, куда она пошла, и никто ел весь день не видел.
(We don't know where she went, and no one has seen her all day.)
The complex sentence is made up of an independent clause and one or more subordinate clauses.
Девочка не пошла в школу, потому что она была больна.
(The girl didn't go to school because she was ill.)

See Also:
Sentences
Declarative Sentences (Statements)
Exclamatory Sentences (Exclamations)
Imperative Sentences (Exclamations)
Subject and Predicate
Subordinate Clauses
Coordinate Conjunctions
Subordinate Conjunctions
Interrogative and Relative Pronouns
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
In Russian, as in English, phrases can play various roles in a sentence. They can be used to replace a part of speech or modify another word in a sentence.

p.a: Sequence of Adjectives in a Noun Phrase

div.p:
See Also:
Nouns
Adjectives
Verbs
Word Formation
History of the Latin Language
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
A noun or a pronoun and the words modifying it constitute a noun phrase:
Ел четырлхлетний мальчик был очень весллым реблнком.
(Her four-year old boy was a very happy child.)
Высокий мужчина сел на стул. .
(The tall man sat down on the chair.)
Покойный брат мисс Смит был очень щедрым человеком.
Miss Smith's late brother was a very generous person.
Он хочет купить самую лучшую из возможных машину.
(He wants to buy the best possible car.)
Мальчик, реблнок, мужчина, мисс Смит, машина
(Boy, child, man, Miss Smith, and car) are nouns. They are modified by adjectives, other nouns and adverbs.
Он ищет чего-нибудь нового и волнующего.
(He is searching for something new and exciting.)
Чего-нибудь (something) is a pronoun and the key element of the noun phrase here; нового и волнующего (new and exciting) are used to modify it.

See Also:
Abstract Noun Phrases
Appositive Noun and Adjective Phrases
Participial Clauses
Phrases with Genitive

Adverbial Phrases
Impersonal Constructions with Dative Case
Special Constructions

A noun or a pronoun and the words modifying it constitute a noun phrase:
Ел четырлхлетний мальчик был очень весллым реблнком.

Он хочет купить самую лучшую из возможных машину.
(He wants to buy the best possible car.)
Мальчик, реблнок, мужчина, мисс Смит, машина
(Boy, child, man, Miss Smith, and car) are nouns. They are modified by adjectives, other nouns and adverbs.
Он ищет чего-нибудь нового и волнующего.
(He is searching for something new and exciting.)
Чего-нибудь (something) is a pronoun and the key element of the noun phrase here; нового и волнующего (new and exciting) are used to modify it.

Adjectives

The Genitive phrase is the equivalent of the English "of" phrase or the "s" to show possession. It is used to express the relationships between nouns:
книга моей сестры (my sister's book)
первый президент Соединлнных Штатов Америки (the first President of the United States)
мешок песка (a bag of sand)
корзина черники (a basket of blackberries)
история войны (a history of the war)
автор книги (the author of the book)
большая часть его текста (a large portion of his text)

See Also:
Noun Phrases
Abstract Noun Phrases
Appositive Noun and Adjective Phrases
Participial Clauses
Sequence of Adjectives in a Noun Phrase
Adverbial Phrases
Impersonal Constructions with Dative Case
Special Constructions
Nouns
Adjectives
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Appositive phrases may be considered an alternate form of an adjective clause.
Compare:
Девочка, которая была весллой и довольной всего минуту назад,
вдруг заплакала. (Adjective clause)
(The girl, who was happy and contented just a minute ago, suddenly started to cry.)
Девочка, весллая и довольная всего минуту назад, вдруг заплакала. (Appositive phrase)
(The girl, happy and contented just a minute ago, suddenly started to cry..)
Nouns, participles, and adjectives can function as appositives:
Литературное влияние Эмерсона- поэта, эссеиста и учителя- было особенно сильным в середине девятнадцатого века. (Nouns as appositive.)
(The literary influence of Emerson - poet, essayist, lecturer - was particularly strong in the midlle of the nineteenth century.)
Весь дом, усталый и сонный, не проснулся от его ночного прихода. (Adjectives as appositive.)
(The whole household, tired and sleepy, was not awakened by his nighttime arrival.)
Артист, больной, одинокий и забытый всеми, умер в приюте. (Adjectives and participle as appositive.)
(The artist, sick, lonely and forgotten by everyone, died in the shelter.)

See Also:
Noun Phrases
Participial Clauses
Phrases with Genitive
Impersonal Constructions with Dative Case
Special Constructions
Nouns
Adjectives
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
In adverbial phrases of time the instrumental case is used:
1. to denote parts of the day:
утром, днлм, вечером, ночью
(in the morning, in the daytime, in the evening, at night)
рано утром (early in the morning),
вчера поздно вечером (yesterday late in the evening)
2. to denote seasons of the year:
зимой, летом, весной, осенью
(in the winter, in the summer, in the spring)
прошлой зимой (last winter),
ранней весной (early in the spring)
In adverbial phrases of manner the instrumental case is also used:
1. to denote means by which the action is performed:
бегом, шагом
(running, at walking pace)
быстрым шагом (at fast walking pace),
2. to denote group activity:
хором, всем классом, всей семьлй
(in chorus, with the whole class, with the whole family)
There are some noun combinations (idioms) which are regarded as adverbial phrases:
шаг за шагом (step after step)
время от времени (from time to time)
изо дня в день (day after day)
вверх дном (upside down)
раз (и) навсегда (once and for all)

See Also:
Noun Phrases
Abstract Noun Phrases
Phrases with Genitive
Sequence of Adjectives in a Noun Phrase
Participial Clauses
Appositive Noun and Adjective Phrases
Impersonal Constructions with Dative Case
Special Constructions
Nouns
Verbs
Participles
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Subordinate clauses in sentences have several functions. Adverbial clauses modify the predicate. Adjectival clauses act as adjectives, modifying a noun, and noun clauses replace a subject or object in the sentence.

p.a: Adverbial Clauses of Cause and Effect
Adverbial Clauses of Conditions and Oppositions

div.p:
See Also:
Sentences
Declarative Sentences (Statements)
Exclamatory Sentences (Exclamations)
Imperative Sentences (Exclamations)
Subject and Predicate
Compound and Complex Sentences
Adjectives
Nouns
Adverbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Adverbial clauses modify the predicate of the main clause. The following conjunctions introduce adverbial clauses:
когда (when)
как только (whenever)
перед тем, как (before),
после того, как (after)
если (as long as, if),
если только (as long as)
Она может начать, как только будет готова.
(She can start as soon as she is ready.)
Помойте руки перед тем, как начнлте есть.
(Wash your hands before you begin to eat.)
После того, как она кончила делать уроки, она пошла спать.
(After she finished her homework she went to bed.)
Eсли ты не болен, ты можешь идти в школу.
(If you are not sick you may go to school.)
Можешь пользоваться моей книжкой до тех пор, пока она тебе нужна.
(You may use my book for as long as you need it.)
Когда я гулял в парке, я видел дерущихся детей.
(When I was walking in the park, I saw children fighting.)

p.a: Adverbial Clauses of Cause and Effect
Adverbial Clauses of Conditions and Oppositions

div.p:
See Also:
Subordinate Clauses
Adjectival Clauses
Noun Clauses
Compound and Complex Sentences
Sentences
Adverbs
Coordinate Conjunctions
Subjunctive or Conditional Mood
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Note that if the future tense is used in the main clause, then the future tense is also used in the adverbial clause (the perfective is used in both clauses):
Я приеду прежде, чем он уедет.
(I will arrive before he leaves.)
Я приехал прежде, чем он уехал.
(I (had) arrived before he left.)
Она отправится в путешествие после того, как окончит институт.
(She will take a trip after she graduates.)
После того, как она окончила институт, она отправилась в путешествие.
(After she had graduated, she took a trip.)
Когда (when) is used to indicate an action occurring at the particular time expressed by the verb of the main clause:
Когда я приехал туда, они всл ещл разговаривали.
(When I got there, they were still talking.)
Когда я приехал туда, они уже поговорили друг с другом.
(When I got there, they had already spoken to each other.)
Пока (as long as) shows the action that continues during the action in the main clause:
Можете оставаться здесь, пока вы ведлте себя тихо.
(You can stay here as long as you are quiet.)

See Also:

item.title: Adverbial Clauses of Cause and Effect

div.p: Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

p.span: Adverbial Clauses of Cause and Effect

div.p: The following conjunctions are used with this type of clause:
потому что (because)
поскольку (since)
теперь когда (now that)
пока (as, as long as)
так что (so... that)
Ему пришлось уйти рано, потому что он отправился к врачу.
(He had to leave early because he went to the doctor’s.)
Поскольку погода была такая плохая, мы решили никуда не идти.
(Since the weather was so bad, we decided not to go out.)
Теперь, когда проект окончен, я могу отдыха ь несколько дней.
(Now that the project is finished, I can take a few days off.)
Пока у тебя есть время, мог бы ты отнести письмо на почту?
(As long as you are free, could you take the letter to the post office for me?)
Он так возбуждлн, что каждая мелочь раздражает его.
(He is so emotional, that every little thing upsets him.)

See Also:
Adverbial Clauses of Time
Adverbial Clauses of Conditions and Oppositions
Adverbial Clauses of Comparison
Adjectival Clauses
Noun Clauses
Subordinate Clauses
Compound and Complex Sentences
Sentences
Adverbs
Conjunctions
Subjunctive or Conditional Mood
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
The following conjunctions are used with the clauses of conditions and oppositions:
если (if)
даже если, если даже (even if)
если только не (unless)
при условии, что (in the event (that))
в случае, если (in case of, providing, provided (that)):
Eсли я его встречу, то приглашу на вечер.
(If I see him, I will invite him to the party.)
Даже если бы я знал о вечеринке, я бы не мог прийти.
(Even if I had known about the party, I couldn't have come.)
Я была бы рада пойти с вами в театр, если я найду няньку для детей.
(I will be glad to go to the theater with you, provided I can get a baby-sitter.)
Маша простила бы мужу всл, если бы только он вернулся.
(Masha would forgive her husband everything, if only he would come back.)
See Real Conditions and Unreal Conditions.

See Also:
Adverbial Clauses of Time
Adverbial Clauses of Cause and Effect
Adverbial Clauses of Comparison
Adjectival Clauses
Noun Clauses
Subordinate Clauses
Compound and Complex Sentences
Sentences
Adverbs
Conjunctions
Subjunctive or Conditional Mood
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Statements with real conditions express different kinds of conditional meanings.
Possibility:
Eсли пойдлт дождь, что мы будем делать?
(If it rains, what will we do?)
В случае, если случится землетрясение, будет много пострадавших.
(In case an earthquake occurs, there will be lots of casualties.)
Supposition:
Eсли предположим, что он был убит, что вы предпримете?
(Let us suppose, that he was killed. What will you do then?)
Note, that if the action takes place in the future (the main clause verb is in the future) the verb in adverbial clause is in the future also (perfective form of verb is used):
Eсли будет хорошая погода, мы устроим пикник.
(If the weather is nice, we will go on a picnic.)
Eсли у нел завтра будет время, она позвонит мне .
(If she has enough time tomorrow, she will call me.)

See Also:
Unreal Conditions
Adverbial Clauses of Conditions
Adverbial Clauses
Adverbial Clauses of Time
Adverbial Clauses of Cause and Effect
Adverbial Clauses of Comparison
Subordinate Clauses
Adjective Clauses
Noun Clauses
Compound and Complex Sentences
Phrases
Sentences
Spelling
Adverbs
Conjunctions
Subjunctive Mood
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Statements with unreal conditions express doubt, uncertainty, improbability about a given situation:
Eсли ему действительно нужны были бы деньги, я бы дал ему.
(If he had really needed money, I would have given him some.)
Eсли бы у меня было время, я бы взял отпуск.
(If I had enough time, I would take a vacation.)
They also express conditions that are impossible to realize at a given time:
(Eсли бы я был) на вашем месте, я бы взял отпуск.
If I were you, I would take a vacation. (impossible at all times)
Eсли бы у меня было достаточно времени, я бы взял отпуск.
If I had had enough time, I would have taken vacation. (impossible to change the past)
Subjunctive forms with бы are used in the conditional clause and in the main clause.

Adverbial clauses of comparison are introduced by чем (than) and так же, как (as...as):
Реблнок оказался умнее, чем я ожидал.
(The child was smarter than I expected.)
Это кончилось гораздо раньше, чем мы предполагали.
(It ended much sooner than we had planned.)
Новая установка так же эффективна , как и старая.
(The new machine is just as efficient as the old one was.)

See Also:
Adverbial Clauses of Time
Adverbial Clauses of Cause and Effect
Adverbial Clauses of Conditions and Oppositions
Adjectival Clauses
Noun Clauses

Compound and Complex Sentences

Conjunctions
Comparative and Superlative Adjectives
Comparative and Superlative Adverbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
The adjective clause (also called relative), similar to an adjective, modifies the preceding noun, noun phrase or pronoun:
Appositive phrases may be considered an alternate form of an adjectival clause.
Compare:
Девочка, которая была весллой и довольной всего минуту назад,
вдруг заплакала. (Adjectival clause)
(The girl, who was happy and contented just a minute ago, suddenly started to cry.)
Девочка, весллая и довольная всего минуту назад, вдруг заплакала. (Appositive phrase)
(The girl, happy and contented just a minute ago, suddenly started to cry.)

See Also:
Adverbial Clauses of Time
Adverbial Clauses of Cause and Effect
Adverbial Clauses of Conditions and Oppositions
Adverbial Clauses of Comparison
Noun Clauses
Subordinate Clauses
Compound and Complex Sentences
Sentences
Adverbs
Conjunctions
Comparative and Superlative Adjectives
Comparative and Superlative Adverbs
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Noun clauses fill the same position and have the same functions as nouns:
Хорошо известно, что лучшее вино производится во Франции.
(It is well known that the best wine is made in France.)
A noun clause may be introduced by что. In this usage что is always preceded by a comma. It is used as a conjunction, not as a pronoun.
Noun clauses occur most frequently as the object of the verb in the main sentence. Compare :
Он жаловался друзьям на свою жену.
(He complained to his friends about his wife.)
Он жаловался друзьям, что его жена плохо готовит.
(He complained to his friends that his wife is a bad cook.)
The verbs in the main clause usually express mental activities or state, and speech:

признать (admit), жаловаться (complain), ответить (answer), помнить (remember), думать (think), убеждать (assure), отметить (note), писать (write), показать (show), учить (teach), предсказать (predict), мечтать (dream), надеяться (hope), желать (wish):
Я не заметил, что он надел очки.
(I didn't notice that he had put on his glasses.)
Я верю, что она честный человек.
(I believe that she is an honest person.)
In informal speech что (that) is frequently omitted from the object clauses:
Я думаю, вам надо сделать это.
(I think you should do that.)
Noun clauses may also begin with relative pronouns in different cases and adverbs:
кто (who), что (what), который (which),
чей (whose), кто бы (however), когда (when, whenever):
Мы не знаем, кто придлт.
(We don't know who is coming.)
Скажите, пожалуйста, на кого он ссылается.
(Please tell me to whom he is referring.)

Punctuation allows us to present our ideas in writing clearly and accurately. It shows the beginning and the end of thoughts, the relationships among ideas, and the conventions in abbreviations and numbers.

See Also:
Sentences
History of the Russian Language
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
A period, as in English, is used at the end of a complete sentence. It is a marker that one thought has ended and that another may follow:
Зима- мол самое любимое время года. (Winter is my favorite time of year.)

See Also:
Punctuation and Punctuation Style
Question Marks
Exclamation Points
Commas
Semicolons
Colons
Quotation Marks
Dashes
Sentences
Declarative Sentences
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
A question mark, as in English, is used at the end of a question:
Вы любите путешествовать? (Do you like to travel?)
Понятно? (Understood?)
Извините, который сейчас час? (Excuse me, what time is it?)

See Also:
Interrogative Sentences(Questions)
Interrogative-Word Questions
Punctuation and Punctuation Style
Periods
Exclamation Points
Commas
Semicolons
Colons
Quotation Marks
Dashes
Sentences
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
An exclamation mark adds emphasis to sentences, phrases, or single words. Exclamation marks are used much more frequently in Russian than in English:
Я так рада вас видеть! (I am so glad to see you!)
Exclamation marks may be put in parenthesis within a sentence to express irony:
Она утверждает, что ел дети спокойные(!) и послушные. (She claims that her children are calm (!) and obedient.)

See Also:
Exclamatory Sentences(Exclamations)
Interjections
Punctuation and Punctuation Style
Periods
Question Marks
Commas
Semicolons
Colons
Quotation Marks
Dashes
Sentences
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
A comma is the most commonly used punctuation mark, and has a variety of functions:
Commas separate words in a series:
На улице было мокро, грязно, холодно. (It was wet, dirty and cold outside.)
На день рождения Груше подарили платья, туфли, игрушки, конфеты. (For her birthday, Grace got dresses, shoes, toys, and sweets.)
Commas are always used after да (yes) and нет (no):
Да, конечно я приду к вам во вторник. (Yes, of course I will come over on Tuesday.)
Нет, я не знаю куда она ушла. (No, I don't know where she went.)
Commas are always used to distinguish participial or gerundial phrases from the rest of the sentence:
Громко смеясь, Плтр обнял сестру. (Loudly laughing, Peter hugged his sister.)
Из облака выглянула луна, побледневшая от холода. (The moon, pale from the cold, peeked out from behind the cloud.)
Commas also separate repeated words:
Беги, беги, а то пропустишь поезд! (Run, run, or you'll miss the train!)
Commas are always used before но (but):
Она красива, но неуклюжа. (She is beautiful, but clumsy.)
Commas are always used in sentences of comparison, before such words as чем and как:
Эта собака умнее, чем та. (This dog is smarter than that one.)
Он ведлт себя, как будто нас не знает. (He acts as if he doesn't know us.)
Commas are used when writing decimals:
Note: Commas are always used before the relative pronouns "что" and "который" and the adverbs "как" and "когда" when these are used as conjunctions.

See Also:
Punctuation and Punctuation Style
Periods
Question Marks
Exclamation Points
Semicolons
Colons
Quotation Marks
Dashes
Sentences
Subordinate Clauses
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
The semicolon functions to separate long clauses that contain commas from the rest of the sentence:
Прошло двадцать лет, и я опять ходил по родному городу; кривые маленькие улицы, соллный запах моря, ласковое Одесское солнце, приносили старые воспоминания.
Ten years had passed, and again I walked the streets of my native town; the crooked streets, the salty sea air, the gentle sun of Odessa, brought back old memories.

See Also:
Punctuation and Punctuation Style
Periods
Question Marks
Exclamation Point
Commas
Colons
Quotation Marks
Dashes
Sentences
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
A colon represents a break that is more complete than a semicolon, but not as complete as a period. A colon is used:
before a list:
Мы растили множество цветов в нашем саду: розы, пионы, лилии и хризантемы. (We grew a multitude of flowers in our garden: roses, peonies, lilies, and chrysanthemums.)
when the second sentence explains the first one:
Вдруг всл стало понятно: кошка съела наш обед. (Suddenly everything became clear: the cat had eaten our dinner.)
When introducing a quotation, or reporting direct speech:
Он ответил: "Я видел его вчера в школе." (He answered: "I saw him in school yesterday.")

See Also:
Punctuation and Punctuation Style
Periods
Question Marks
Exclamation Point
Commas
Semicolons
Quotation Marks
Dashes
Sentences
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

Quotation marks, as in English, enclose the direct quotation that is the repetition of someone's exact words. Titles of books are placed in quotation marks as well. Quotation marks can be written in two distinct ways in Russian. Although both of them are grammatically acceptable, the style called "guillemetes," the double pointed brackets, is the most commonly used:
Достоевский написал мою любимую книгу-«Братья Карамазовы». (Dostoyevsky wrote my favorite book- Brothers Karamazov.)
Она прошептала: "Спрячь меня, Аллша". (She whispered: "Hide me, Alexei.")

See Also:
Punctuation and Punctuation Style
Periods
Question Marks
Exclamation Point
Commas
Semicolons
Colons
Dashes
Sentences
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
A dash has several major functions in Russian:
It is often used in place of the present tense verb "to be":
Мой конь -- самый быстрый. (My horse is the fastest one.)
It is often used instead of quotation marks to convey reported speech, especially when the speech is in dialogue form:
-- Как вас зовут? ("What's your name?")
-- Меня зовут Виктор . ("My name is Victor.")
The dash can also be used before a clause that explains the beginning of the sentence:
Музей недалеко -- поверните налево и пройдите два квартала. (The museum is not far - turn left and walk two blocks.)

See Also:
Punctuation and Punctuation Style
Periods
Question Marks
Exclamation Point
Commas
Semicolons
Colons
Quotation Marks
Ellipses
Sentences
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Ellipses points are used more frequently in Russian than they are in English and are often not translated. They can be used to express:
An unfinished statement, often said in a wistful tone:
Он стоял на палубе, и смотрел на удаляющийся в золотом закате родной город...
(He stood on the deck and watched his native city recede in the golden sunset...)
Hesitation:
Ты знаешь кто разбил вазу? (Do you know who broke the vase?)
Нет,... не знаю. (No,... I don't know.)

See Also:
Punctuation and Punctuation Style
Periods
Question Marks
Exclamation Point
Commas
Semicolons
Colons
Quotation Marks
Dashes
Sentences
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

In general, spelling of Russian words reflects the meaning of each part of the word (prefix, root, suffix, grammatical ending) and not necessarily the pronunciation. Pronunciation is largely dependent on stress and position in a word. There are a few spelling rules that are important to remember and special rules that affect some prefixes and prepositions.

See Also:
Letters and Sounds
Prefixes
Prepositions
Punctuation and Punctuation Style
Sentences
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
1. The consonants г, к, х, ж, ч, ш, щ are followed by а, и, у and never by я, ы, ю:
жить (live)
куча (heap)
чаща (thicket)
чай (tea)
A few foreign words are exceptions:
жюри (jury),
парашют (parachute)
2. The consonant ц is followed by а, and у and never by я, ю:
цапля (heron)
курицу (hen [dative case])
3. Stems ending in ж, ш, ч, щ, ц are followed by -о only if stressed. They may be followed by -е in both stressed and unstressed syllables:
лицо (face)
лицемерие (hypocrisy)
в лице (in the face)

See Also:
Consonants
Devoicing of Final Consonants
Vowels and Diphthongs
Letters and Sounds
Spelling Rules
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
Prefixes which end in a consonant (в, вз, под, об, от, с) are followed by ъ (the hard sign) when the root starts with a vowel:
въехать в город, (to ride into the city) from ехать (to ride),
объесть кость (to eat around the bone) from есть ( to eat),
нельзя объять необъятное (it is impossible to contain the infinite) from объять
отъезд из города (departure from the city) from ездить .
The prefixes из-, над-, от-, под-, с- may add -o to form the prefixes изо-, надо-, ото-, -подо-, со-. This occurs when they precede a root with unusual and hard to pronounce consonant clusters:
The prefix из-has the form ис- if the root starts with a voiceless consonant:

See Also:
Prefixes
Letters and Sounds
Spelling Rules
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic

See Also:
History of the Russian Language
Contents | Previous Topic | Next Topic
There are two numbers in Russian: singular and plural.
Most nouns in Russian have singular and plural forms:
семья, семьи ((the) family, (the) families)

See
Nouns

Pronouns also have singular and plural forms:

td.p: мой, моя, мол (mine [singular, masculine, feminine, neuter])

Adjectives and ordinal numerals agree with nouns in number (and also in gender).

See
Adjectives
Noun Adjective Agreement
Ordinal Numerals
Verbs and different verbal forms (present and past participles) agree with the nouns and pronouns they describe in number:
Мы пойдлм на прогулку.
(We will go for a walk.)
Пойдлм is 1st person plural, future tense, perfective of the verb пойти. It agrees in number with the personal pronoun мы.

Grammatical person indicates the relationship of speaker or writer to the rest of the sentence.
First person refers to the speaker or to the speaker group: я, мы (I, we).
Second person refers to whoever is being spoken to: ты, вы (you).
Third person refers to the entity being spoken about: он/она/оно, они (he/she/it, they).

There are three genders in Russian: masculine, feminine, and neuter.

Although there are no rules by which the gender of all nouns can be determined, the gender of many nouns can be determined by their meaning or their ending. The gender of other nouns must be learned individually.

See
Nouns
Gender of Nouns
Masculine Nouns
Feminine Nouns
Neuter Nouns

Knowing the gender of every noun is important not only for the noun itself, but for the spelling and pronunciation of the words it influences in a sentence: adjectives, participles, ordinal numerals, the cardinal numerals 1 and 2, and pronouns. They agree in gender and in number with the noun.
